column1: It's too bad most Americans have only read one book on globalization
column2: i.e.
column3: Firedman's middlebrow
column4: misinfomed tome. Friedman makes "arguments by assertion
column5: assertions based not on documented facts, but on stories from friends and elite CEOs he visits --not even one footnote reference. Yet his book influences business and government leaders around the globe. By what it leaves out, it does nothing more than misinform the American people and our leaders.  Actually, the world isn't flat; it's tilted in favor of unfettered global corporations that exploit cheap labor in China, India and beyond. Instead I suggest you read, The World is Flat?" by Aronica & Ramdo. This concise monograph brings clarity to many of Friedman's misconceptions
column6: and explores nine key issues that Friedman largely ignores
column7: including the hollowing out of America's debt-ridden middle class. To create a balanced exploration of globalization
column8: the authors cite the work of experts that Friedman fails to incorporate
column9: including Nobel laureate and former Chief Economist at the World Bank
column10: Dr. Joseph Stiglitz.   Refreshingly
column11: you can now gain new insights into globalization without weeding through Friedman's almost 600 pages of ill-informed
column12: grandiloquent prose and bafflegab

column1: This book was an OK read
column2: not a bad book
column3: but nothing spectacular either. The writing seemed to drone on without any real punch and it never did foster any real excitement for the evolving story of New York as the center of the art world. The book misses a great opportunity to do something significant with an interesting subject. It mostly felt like a narrative of events punctuated by passages of overwrought artspeak. The word "dialectic" was used much too many times.  When I finished the book I'm not sure what I read. The only new insights that I developed from the book came from the discussion about Fairfield Porter.    The book suffers from being published at about the same time as the much more captivating Stevens & Swans' "De Kooning: An American Master" which covers much of the same ground but is a more interesting read.

column1: since there is little to no mystery involved in the story.  I should have expected this
column2: since this has been the trend for the last 4 or 5 books in the series.  I had put off reading this one for precisely that reason but needed something to read for the weekend so I decided to give it a try.  The best thing that can be said about this "Turkey" is that it's a quick read
column3: so it's good for a plane ride
column4: but if you want something that remotely resembles a mystery pass this one up and read one of the first books by this author which really were engaging and satisfying mysteries.    Even as a glimpse into the small town life of Moose County this one falls flat.  It used to be that one of the charms of the series was the way Braun had developed the world of Moose County and all the foibles of its inhabitants and if tragedy struck one you really felt for them.  In this book
column5: characters from previous books are randomly introduced and they wander around aimlessly and there is no emotional depth to Qwill's relationship with any of them.     The other problem that has happened to the series is that Braun fell in love with her own character.  Qwill started the series as a flawed charcter.  In "Turkey" there is even more rapturous description of Qwill's mustache and wonderful voice than usual
column6: not to mention the ovations for the ridiculous Big Storm production.  We are supposed to believe that it is so well received that there are to be several performances a week throughout the summer - how big is the population of Moose county?    SPOILER ALERT:  But to cap off the ridiculousness of this book
column7: Qwill leaves his beloved Koko out in the gazebo with a confessed murderer who is strung out on drugs.  The Qwill of past books would never have intentionally put either cat in danger like this.    According to her fan club web page
column8: she was born in 1916 so now she's pushing 90.  It's possible she's in poor health. Because of this I'm willing to give her the benefit of the doubt and agree with those who suggest this book was ghost-written based on notes she made.  That would account for inconsistencies in plot and style.  The only good part of this book - the only reason it deserves even one star - is the description of YumYum playing with her thimble (but even it is taken from another of Braun's books).  It's on page 72 - read it
column9: then find something else to read.

This book provides a broad overview of some of the issues behind the Simplicity movement.  The author
column2: Cecile Andrews set up a number of Simplicity study circles near her home in the Northwest.  This book reveals some of the factors that led her to become interested in Simplicity as well as her ideas of how Simplicity study circles might work.  Much of the beginning of the book provides justification for adopting Simplicity.  Andrews enumerates problems such as hyper-consumption
column3: environmental degradation
column4: and personal isolation.  She also explores possible actions we could take to solve these problems
column5: such as consciously building community with other people and the earth
column6: finding ways to express our spirituality
column7: and restructuring our economic system to make it more environmentally and socially friendly. In the last part of the book
column8: she describes the idea of Simplicity study circles
column9: the benefits that might be gained from participating in one
column10: and how a study circle should operate.  She also provides a 10-week study plan based on the earlier material in the book.  Although I agree with the ideas in this book
column11: I found the book rather disappointing in content.  Much of the discussion is either so personal as to be hard to generalize
column12: or else a superficial summary of other more substantial texts.  For example
column13: Andrews frequently refers to findings of Juliet Schor; readers would have more material for discussion by reading Schor's works directly.  Some of Andrews' suggestions for addressing problems are rather inappropriate.  To draw attention to hyper-consumerism
column14: she suggests surreptitiously clothes-pinning tags with messages like "You don't really need this
column15: do you?" inside articles of clothing in shops.  While I'm all for trying to get people to become more aware of their needless purchases
column16: I don't think messing with the property of individual store owners is an acceptable way to go about the mission.  Her suggestions for reforming our economic system would be great in an ideal state
column17: but until we are run by a benevolent socialist dictator
column18: I don't think they can realistically be put into action.  It would be better to focus our efforts on goals that are conceivably achievable.  Overall
column19: while I found the topic of this book interesting
column20: I think there are numerous other books on the topic of Simplicity that are better implemented
column21: starting with Joe Dominguez and Vicki Robin's "Your Money or Your Life".  It's hard to tell from this book if Andrews can take credit for originating Simplicity study groups such as those run by the Northwest Earth Institute.  If so
column22: she certainly deserves credit for her efforts in that area
column23: but I don't think there's enough substantial material in this volume to use as background reading for an effective study group by itself.

column1: Calleman was a well regarded biological researcher.  A quick query will turn up many serious
column2: scientific papers on chemical toxicology
column3: carcinogens and a variety of other very complex research topics.  Alas
column4: this book is not one of them.  In writing this text Calleman puports to connect the Mayan calendar with some unifying theory of human consciousness.  He tends to ignore several basic tenets of any good treatise.  First of all
column5: there are no substantial references in this work.  Nothing is footnoted and a number of the assertions and claims are attributed to "an unpublished work" of his own.    This is only compounded by the wandering writing style of this book.  It almost seems as if it is a compilation of essays and notes rather than a cohesive postulation.  Calleman makes no sound argument for the reader to understand the Mayan calendar.  He ignores several significant Mayan sites
column6: such as Copan
column7: and a wide body of archaelogical work which would invailidate his theory.  As one critic pointed out
column8: he takes a decidedly Swedish and Christian view of his theory. This occuldes any potential scholarly understanding of his statements and converts what I had hoped to be an interesting intellectual journey into more New Age pop philosophy.  Avoid this and seek out some truly legitimate work on the Mayan culture.  They are a fascinating people without all the ridiculous attributes being foisted upon them

column1: I had such high hopes for this book
column2: based on its description.  And in spite of the author's sometimes hard-to-follow writing style - she does love to start in one place and wander quite far from the original subject before finally winding her way back - for the first few chapters I managed to hold on to those hopes.    But in the end
column3: I would have to classify this book as 80 percent disappointment.  Charlotte is set up to be a very sympathetic character: Married to a man she loves
column4: but trapped in the family home surrounded by a seemingly endless supply of in-laws (also all residents of the family home)
column5: none of whom have ever made much of an effort to make her feel a part of the family.  Charlotte has been unable to bear a child to term in all the years of the marriage
column6: and her 10 months in a sickbed seem to have put the final distance between her and her husband
column7: Hays.  Finally
column8: after an inexplicable recovery (the author never bothers to give any hint of why Charlotte is suddenly well after all this time)
column9: Charlotte is off to surprise her husband at the wake for one of his recently deceased uncles.  But what she encounters is Hays and a mystery woman
column10: just about to share a kiss.   Calling in a favor from the local baker and his wife
column11: Charlotte finds herself at the hotel of the title
column12: facing a chilly reception from Mrs. Petty - the former cook in Charlotte's in-law's house - who had been the one to first tell Charlotte about the hotel. (Though not about the details of what goes on there.)  To this point
column13: the book was enjoyable.  But once Charlotte lands in the hotel
column14: the book heads into a decline from which it never recovers.    The efforts of the hotel's owner
column15: his staff and Charlotte's Aunt Lily - a surprise "regular" at the hotel - to get Charlotte out of the hotel were understandable
column16: if a little tedious.  Arthur's attachment to Charlotte is pretty sudden
column17: and regardless of how she feels about Hays' cheating on her
column18: it seems a little odd that she would embark on an affair with Arthur quite so easily.  And unless the author is planning a sequel
column19: there were things in this book that just didn't seem to have a reason for being.  Charlotte's introduction to the hotel owner's wife and her servant
column20: for example.  An interesting enough scene
column21: but to what purpose?    The artist who created all the paintings in the hotel - introduced
column22: then killed off.   Mrs. Petty and her children - suddenly packed off to another situation
column23: for the good of the children.  Sure
column24: we learn who the father of one of the children is
column25: but again - why?  Charlotte's parents
column26: who have been conspicuously absent from Charlotte's thoughts for a good portion of the book - there's no purpose to their appearance at the end
column27: nor really to Charlotte's search for them.  The ending
column28: as mentioned by another reviewer
column29: is the worst part of the book.  Why does Charlotte do what she does when she leaves the hotel?  Is it guilt
column30: a desire for reconciliation?    Charlotte frustrates me...I don't know what she wants
column31: and most of the time she doesn't seem to know
column32: either.  In the end
column33: I didn't care much about this book
column34: except to wonder about the several chapters that seemed to have been lopped off the end.  Maybe they would have wrapped things up in a better fashion.  I won't read this book again
column35: and I certainly can't recommend it to others.

column1: I was rather disappointed in Mr. Peterson's work. He dwells much too long on trying to convince us of "the problem". Nearly the first half of the book is spent on statistic overload!  Even after wading through the  numbers and graphs
column2: I am still skeptical of his conclusions and would  caution readers to do further research.  Certainly the Baby Boomers are an  aging bulge in the population of the US and will create some challenges.   However
column3: the author fails to mention the "echo boom" (baby  boomer's children which are equal in number) and he glosses over the impact  of the huge young immigration population that comes into the country every  year.  Both of these facts will "soften" the impact of the  "Gray Doom" that Mr. Peterson tries to create.  I just don't  anticipate the tremendous problem of which  he tries to make us aware.  But  I did find interesting the apparently huge impact that abortions and birth  control will have on our future. Another disappointment was very little  discussion of aging trends and buying habits. Despite these shortcomings
column4: I  enjoyed parts of the book and it stimulated thinking about the future and  the impact of aging populations

column1: This tape really doesn't show you how to do all of the cuts listed.  In fact
column2: you don't ever see a complete groom from start to finish and all of the dogs are show dogs who stand perfectly still without the use of a grooming tether.  The tape also assumes a certain amount of knowledge about grooming and grooming tools; she tells you the name of the tools but not why she choose them or which breeds to use them on.  I was expecting a step by step video including expert tips on grooming but it was more a "show" with occasional comments tossed out.  The groomer almost seemed bored with her job!  I purchased it so that our novice volunteers could learn about grooming but I don't see how it will help educate them.  We'll probably never use it

column1: As a stand-alone story (not a "prequel")
column2: this book is relatively fun - if you can ignore the countless glaring grammatical errors and typos. I can't believe this made it past editing!   As far as being a prequel to Barrie's Peter Pan
column3: this book misses the mark. There are too many blatant inconsistencies for this to be anything but a shallower "re-telling" of Barrie's richly woven classic. These are not the characters we knew and loved; this is not the Never Land we dreamed about at night. Pixie dust is now nothing more than "space dust" which causes strange and unpredictable genetic mutations on contact. Need I say more

column1: First
column2: I should say that I haven't yet heard any of the Oasis records made after this one. Like most people I got into Oasis (as well as Blur) during the Definitely Maybe/Morning Glory years. When I heard "Be Here Now" I couldn't help wondering if the band had lost its edge. I liked The Master Plan a lot
column3: but as it was more a loose collection of B-sides than an album in its own right
column4: I didn't read it as indicative of a specific musical direction.   By the time I bought a cassette of SOTSOG during an April 2000 trip to the UK
column5: my Britpop tastes had moved on to Stereophonics
column6: Belle & Sebastian and Badly Drawn Boy. I listened to that cassette in my rental car all during the trip. I wasn't crazy about it. I really liked a couple songs
column7: but when I got back to the US I put the tape away and rarely ever listened to it until a few weeks ago.  So
column8: my take on SOTSOG:  Noel Gallagher has always written trite lyrics
column9: but the triteness was forgivable because his songs had great hooks and were loud and noisy and made you want to jump around. SOTSOG shows that when Noel goes mellow
column10: his lyrics quickly go from innocuous to annoying - and these songs generally aren't hooky enough to compensate.   Letting Liam join the songwriting guild was not a smart remedial step; at this stage
column11: Liam's simply a juvenile songwriter. I don't oppose the mellowing of Oasis
column12: but if they are going to turn the noise down they're going to have to ratchet up the hook quotient or come up with some more sophisticated lyrics. Noel's mellow tunes on The Master Plan ("Going Nowhere"
column13: "The Masterplan") came closer to achieving this balance.  That said
column14: the album has a few highlights. The Celtic raga-hymn "Who Feels Love" is one of the band's best songs
column15: ever; since the CD-single of this song is more expensive than SOTSOG
column16: the album is worth buying for this one song alone. Also
column17: "Go Let It Out" is pretty much vintage Oasis
column18: bright and crisp.  I like where Noel Gallagher is going. I'm interested to see if Oasis' post-SOTSOG output is better

column1: Television news reporter (now there's a credential) Shenkman attempts to debunk some widely-held but erroneous beliefs about American history from Columbus to the present day
column2: covering topics such as sex
column3: family
column4: the so-called good old days
column5: arts and quotations. It's a fine and admirable idea for a book.  Unfortunately
column6: this book does not deliver the idea's promise.  Shenkman uses nearly no primary sources
column7: relying on modern historians' research.  This gives the result that in many instances
column8: his "proof" of the falsity of one claim is simply another author's claim.  Shenkman also has an odd idea of what constitutes American history
column9: often resorting to 17th-century history to refute claims of what "American" life really is.  He also quotes extensively but cites sources sproadically
column10: often lumping a few paragraph's worth of sources together in one footnote.  There are one or two nuggets of good stuff in here
column11: like the origin of Paul Bunyan
column12: or some of Harvard's history
column13: but the lack of primary sources and generally non-scholarly approach make this book somewhat interesting at best.

column1: Mark Galli's book helps to shed light upon Jesus's character -- instead of the "warm and fuzzy" Jesus some people follow

column3: "demanding"
column4: "fear and shame-maker"
column5: "forsaker"

column7: but more often than not found that what he writes was really out of context with the entire passage the verses came from.    Many of the chapters made me feel uncomfortable -- not because the book was doing it's job of changing my perspective of Jesus -- but rather the author's stretching of the truth.  For example
column8: he wrote "So we struggle with Jesus in such moments because he so willing employs shame and fear and physical intimidation to motivate people."  His quote refers to Mark 11:15-17.  None of the versions of the Bible mention this scenario with Jesus actually using "shame" tactics; it's the author's own interpretation.  My main concern is that someone who takes Galli's ideas to heart will become demanding
column9: impatient

column11: mean followers of Jesus.  And not in a good way.

column6:
when it comes to financial status I have to make an exception.  There are lots of good men out there (I'm seeing one right now, he's not a well-to-do CEO type and I don't care).  And folk revivalism is what it is, folks; I'll label it even if the populists fume at me because I know of more than 5 genres. He even did an album of covers" of Shirley Collins' arrangements of British traditionals

column1: "Nobody touches the Lonely Planet for budget travel advice
column2: states the back cover of this book.   I just finished travelling around Southeast Asia with this as my primary guidebook. It includes the basics for getting around, eating, etc... but it really is just the basics. I have used other books from the lonely planet series in the past, and have found them good enough to continue using, at least until this volume. It has been 5 years since I was in this region last, and things have changed. Especially the guidebook, which was once a rich trove of off-the-beaten-path hints and tips. Increasingly, however, it seems that the Lonely Planet authors seem less interested in helping you find a unique experience and more interested in serving up a cookie-cutter, package tourist rehash. I have a couple grievances with this book:    -It insists on constantly pointing out little sidebars entitled Splurge!" which indicate ways that the budget traveller can spend a great deal of money in one shot. Why this is in a travel guide called "shoestring" I couldn't tell you. Neither do the authors
column3: but I suppose we can assume that backpackers are interested in spending $5 a night for a couple of months and then blowing $150 to stay in some posh hotel in Kuala Lumpur or racking up an additional $20 in credit card debt for an entirely forgettable dining experience in Bangkok. I just don't feel these are relevant to 99% of actual budget travellers
column4: but they waste a lot of space that could be much better used on greater detail. But I will get to that in a minute.    -Another issue I have is the lack of actual information about actually moving from one place to the next cheaply.  Cheap local transport is available in many of the places covered in the book.  For some reason though
column5: the book usually offers helpful advice like 'just take a cab
column6: ' or 'buses are so cheap
column7: so don't bother with local transport.'  As an independent traveler that actually enjoys saving money AND spending time with the locals (what's the purpose of traveling again?!?!)
column8: I regret the lack of information about local transport.    -The maps in the book
column9: though better than some in past editions
column10: leave much to be desired. Streets are incorrectly labeled or in the wrong place
column11: intersections are vaguely marked
column12: and occasionally they add a street that doesn't exist or remove a street that does. Worst of all
column13: in a region that prides itself on an almost complete lack of road signage
column14: not many good landmarks are given to orient oneself. There is little that is less fun on the road than standing in front of a train station
column15: staring at one's new alien surroundings
column16: being hassled by touts who are trying to steer you in the wrong direction while trying to find that cheap hostel you read about.    Look
column17: if you want a run-of-the-mill book to complete a run-of-the-mill trip
column18: by all means
column19: you will find this book quite helpful.  But if you are looking for that individual experience that is the beauty of independent travel
column20: you might be best going with a different guide for this region.    By the way
column21: the quote I wrote at the beginning should be viewed as a warning rather than an enticemen

column1: Pity the student using this textbook for a Differential Equations course. The Boyce & DiPrima text is unduly cumbersome with lacking explanation and poorly choosen examples throughout.   Many problems given in the text are tedious
column2: and are indicated as being "technologically intensive." This is fine: in today's workplace
column3: one can anticipate using a computer to solve problems. Unfortunately
column4: none of my math professors will let me bring out my laptop on an exam. In some of the chapters
column5: almost every problem is indicated as being "technologically intensive." If the computer-oriented problems weren't bad enough
column6: the examples in the text are. Most of these are sorely unclear. I think that Boyce & DiPrima must have been writing in Fermat's marginal notes style when composing this text. Many times the omitted steps (which the authors sometimes regard as "it is clear that") require substantial algebraic and calculus manipulation to achieve the indicated results. Certainly I have no qualms about a text leaving out algebraic or even trigonometric simplifications
column7: but what's left out of the Boyce & DiPrima examples is truely excessive. Worse
column8: still
column9: the examples are often very generic to a single type of problem. Thus
column10: while one type of problem in the exercises might have good examples to instruct students on how to achieve solutions
column11: the rest of the exercises often lack example altogether. Explanation and orientation to applied math is poor. The authors jump suddenly from a confusing theory discourse to an application without bridging the two. Many times I was left puzzled by how the text was proceeding. Still many more times I set the book aside in frustration.  This book does
column12: however
column13: have redeeming values. I like how all of the problems have their solutions provided in the back. If only other math textbook authors took the hint: students won't know how well they're doing if they cannot confirm their results! Also
column14: the included software is good. I found it easy to use and helpful for the computing problems. I wish
column15: however
column16: more attention was given to this software in the text (like small projects using the software with each chapter). These benefits unfortunately do not overcome the tremendous flaws with the Boyce & DiPrima text.  Overall
column17: this is one of the worst math books I have encountered. Rife with poor explanation
column18: a confusing style
column19: and poor exercise sets
column20: the Boyce and DiPrima textbook is bound to cause grief for most students. The student's solution manual is helpful
column21: but offers only little more explanation than the textbook. If you are hapless enough to have this text as a course requirement
column22: I recommend that you either swap classes to try and get a course with a different book - or - be prepared to spend many long hours with tutors or your professor.  Good luck.  [...

I never would have believed that someone could talk so much without having anything to say. I'm positively amazed.  I've waded through this book for hours trying to find even a shred of a concept among the heaped piles of trivia
column2: irrelevancies
column3: flawed arguments
column4: bold and baseless assertions
column5: large amounts of poorly analyzed information and fantastically impractical propositions
column6: not to mention the incessant repetitions of said.   The fact is
column7: this book contains neither illuminating theories nor useful practical suggestions
column8: but only seemingly random (albeit grammatically compatible) sentences strung together in what must be the most extravagant display of Da-Da intellectualism to ever see print.   For example
column9: after stating that on the one hand
column10: the merging of games and stories seems natural and desirable
column11: and on the other hand it has proven more difficult than expected (by whom?)
column12: the author treats us to this piece of sublime poetry:  "The quest to find a way to combine storytelling and gaming has all the qualities of a great story or game: there's a noble goal to be achieved
column13: difficulties to overcome through understanding and insight
column14: and success to be won by the careful use of skill
column15: planning and execution".  This self-indulgent babble fills the book's pages to the point of choking. Another episode of it is exemplified when the author is considering the proper term to call users of his "participatory storytelling" idea
column16: kindly sharing his profound thinking processes with the reader:  "What shall we call the people participating in these stories? I like players; someone taking part in a game is called a player
column17: as is a performer in a play or film. Since a person participating in a story environment is doing a bit of each activity
column18: the term "player" seems both fitting and economical".  Thanks to Mr. Glassner for his enlightening elucidations.  Later in the book
column19: the author arrives at a conclusion that several difficulties that he claims to be inherent to interactive storytelling require the transition to a new aesthetic goal
column20: which he calls "participatory storytelling". In addition to the fact that it is impossible to yield from this text either an intelligent overview of these difficulties
column21: a coherent argument as to the superiority of "participatory storytelling"
column22: or even a solid definition of it
column23: it seems the author has actually no grasp of the considerations relating to the subject matter. Mr. Glassner suggests
column24: for example
column25: the use of a fantastic science fiction technology he calls "living masks". A living mask
column26: we are told
column27: is a form of "interpreter" assigned to the player
column28: who translates that player's input into the story world
column29: transforming it into a more professional performance. In other words
column30: this "mask" is supposed to be able to understand the player's intention
column31: and then express it in a way that is more theatrical and more "in character" than a non-professional player would be able (or
column32: Mr. Glassner claims
column33: would want) to achieve. A computer rephrasing a human's speech to be more theatrical! Changing his tone to express more emotion! Manipulating his facial expressions to be more like "professional" acting! If this is at all possible
column34: which is in doubt
column35: this technology would certainly consume lifetimes to achieve!    But technology is not the only thing that the author seems to have no grasp of. Not by a long shot. The book drudges through an exhausting overview of what differentiates stories from games (Based
column36: of course
column37: on the mislead assumption that Story + Game = Interactive Storytelling). Since this comparison is about as appropriate as asking what differentiates a symphony from a papaya
column38: Mr. Glassner has to invent some highly imaginative points of comparison which
column39: other than providing an opportunity for several obscene atrocities committed against the English language as regards the definition of certain terms
column40: stretched beyond recognition to be applicable to both stories and games
column41: like the claim that both stories and games have a "referee" of some sort
column42: have very little value. But even within his own twisted semantics
column43: he simply doesn't seem to grasp the core concepts. When comparing the rules of games to those of stories
column44: he focuses on stories
column45: saying that their rules are hard to define because they are dependant on many practicalities - the laws of physics
column46: the capabilities of the characters
column47: or the ramifications of some actions. He's got it all backwards - all of these are the exact considerations which decide the rules of computer games. Stories
column48: all stories
column49: have one
column50: and only one constant and inescapable set of rules - the rules of narrative.   It seems Mr. Glassner's understanding of interactivity is no better than his understanding of storytelling or games. He bemoans what he calls "The Myth of Interactivity: more interactivity makes any experience better". It's hard to say who exactly Mr. Glassner thinks are the subscribers to this "myth". After all
column51: I've yet to hear someone express a wish that food or music
column52: for example
column53: were interactive
column54: however that could possibly be achieved
column55: yet these activities are among those most enjoyed by people the world over.  The examples given by Mr. Glassner serve both to undermine his point as to the overestimation of interactivity and to demonstrate that he
column56: himself
column57: has no idea of what interactivity is:  "Interactivity itself is hardly novel or interesting: an ATM is interactive... and the automatic doors in front of a supermarket are interactive. The whole world is filled with interactive experiences
column58: from waving down a cab to sharpening a pencil".  For all of these activities save the last
column59: the author is correct in claiming that they are
column61: interactive. The part about the pencil sharpening is outright puzzling. However
column62: all these activities are perfect examples of why increased interactivity is better: first
column64: silliest forms of interactivity. Supporting a claim to the overestimation of interactivity with these examples is like supporting a claim to the overestimation of reading with the example of bumper stickers. Furthermore
column65: each and every one of these activities could be improved with more interactivity. The interaction with an ATM would be much more interesting if
column67: it gave you financial advice instead of just spewing out cash
column68: listening to your concerns and recommending a proper course of action. A door at the supermarket would be much more interesting if you could ask it for directions to the different products you're looking for
column69: and a cab ride is improved immeasurably if you have an engaging conversation with the driver. Improve the interactivity of these experiences
column70: and you improve their value (To learn more about interactivity
column71: read Chris Crawford's book on the subject
column73: read his one on interactive storytelling
column74: too).    What passes for a main argument in this forgettable book is that interactivity and stories conflict because stories are meticulously construed by master craftsmen and therefore cannot brook interference from the audience without being destroyed. And since this "interference" is the essence of interactivity
column75: the two are incompatible. If Mr. Glassner were correct
column76: which he most certainly is not
column77: then it would be impossible to wed the two - this would be a shotgun marriage with neither party gaining anything
column78: and the only question being how much each would lose on behalf of the other. As Mr. Glassner would have it
column79: the interactive part would lose dramatically while the story would lose little (The storyteller retains control of the main characters
column81: with the players making secondary contributions). An understandable position for a screenwriter.  However
column82: what the author fails to see is that story and interactivity can actually be combined in a way that benefits both parties instead of simply making both lose their soul. This
column84: requires a major paradigm shift because it is simply impossible to deal with the concept in the terms of current artistic media. The result will be nothing like traditional games and it will be nothing like traditional stories. It will have a different contract between storyteller and audience than that Mr. Glassner is howling like a frenzied fundamentalist to preserve
column85: and it will have a very different kind of interactivity than that of a computer game
column86: let alone the sports games that Mr. Glassner seems so interested in for some reason (being
column88: the farthest thing from relevant to the subject which can still be termed "game")
column89: and it will have a very different definition for the role of storyteller - to create a system of narrative possibilities out of which hundreds of thousands of moving and powerful stories can be constructed using the user's input. Is it possible? Yes. Do we have the technology? Yes. Will Mr. Galssner's book take us any closer to it? Don't bet on it.              After having despaired and having been irritated beyond measure in my attempts to extract even a modicum of benefit or interest from this oversized doorstop
column90: I literally threw it away with force. Avoid doing the same with your time and money.

column1: "The Best of A Flock of Seagulls" is a greatest hits collection for the synth-pop group A Flock of Seagulls.   Many people consider A Flock of Seagulls a one-hit wonder band because they basically had one hit "I Ran".   However
column2: this probably is an unfair statement because this group actually won a grammy award for the instrumental song "D.N.A." and they did score another hit back in England with the song "Wishing (If I Had a Photographh of You).    The "Best of A Flock of Seagulls" contains all of these songs plus another 9 songs.   It does an excellent job of capturing the hits from the group during the period of 1982 through 1985.   This period also coincides with the peak period of the synth-pop era of the 1980s.  As the synth-pop era began to fade into oblivion
column3: so did A Flock of Seagulls.  For a greatest hits collection
column4: there are probably two ways it can be judged.  The first is on the actual music itself and how good the music sounds.   The second way is simply on how good a job the collection compiles the hits.   "The Best of A Flock of Seagulls" does a pretty good job at capturing the music from the various albums of 1982 through 1985.   The collection takes songs from the first four albums.  These albums are: the self-titled "A Flock of Seagulls;  "Listen"; "The Story of a Young Heart"; and "Dream Come True" (each subsequent album listed seems to get harder to find - with the "Dream Come True" album almost impossible to get).    The collection also does a nice job at balancing the music.   But in the first area on how good the music sounds - this is where I have some doubts.   It is not that I am anti-Synth-Pop.  In fact there are many Synth-Pop bands I like.   As for A Flock of Seagulls
column5: they have some moments with some really good melodies
column6: but despire the catchy lyrics
column7: the vocal tracks leave a lot to be desired.   I almost think while Mike Score has some interesting vocals
column8: they just don't overwhelm you anywhere.  One place where A Flock of Seagulls really shines is in the instrumental area.    D.N.A. is a track that does a great job at showing this.   It won a grammy award for an instrumental for a reason - it is pretty good.   "The Story of a Young Heart" is the title track from the third album.   This song has a very good (long) instrumental intro.   This song has more of a new-wave feel to it and it probably is an underrated song.  The hit song "I Ran" came along at the right time.   This was a song from the self-titled debut album when the Synth-Pop movement was in full swing.   This song seemed to fit the Synth-Pop movement like a glove - great keyboards and catchy lyrics.  In addition the song had a perfect theme for the "Space Invaders" period - it dealt with a Close Encounter of the Third Time.  "I Ran" seems to have all of the characteristics of a legendary song - and in some ways the song is legendary based on all of the reasons described.   But there is one problem with the song - it wears on you and will wear on you pretty quickly.  In some ways
column9: the song is the epitomy of the one-hit wonder.    The "space theme" continues with the second song - "Space Age Love Song".  This was the song that followed "I Ran" on the self-titled debut album.   Although it has the "Space Age" in it
column10: there really isn't anything related to the "Space Age" other than the sound.   This song actually is pretty good.    It is kind of the opposite of "I Ran" in one way - this will be the kind of song you listen to a few times and it will grow on you - although I wouldn't go as far to say that you will be addicted to this song.   There will be some good drum (machine) sounds to close out the song.  Again
column11: the vocals don't impress.    The third song (also from the self-titled debut album) "Telecommunication" continues the techo-theme.   It is here where the album begins to wear on you.  The song "The More You Live
column12: The More You Love" is from the second album
column13: "Listen".  This is an interesting song - it has a similar sound to "Space Age Love Song".  This song will also slowly grow on you.  Like "Space Age"
column14: I don't think this will be a song you get addicted to.  The collection contains two versions of "Wishing (I Had a Photograph of You)".   The sixth track is the version of "Wishing" that was released on the "Listen" album.  The 11th track is a nine minute extended version of the song (probably released as a 12" song).    Each of these two versions have a nice catchy beat
column15: but the vocals just don't overwhelm me in these songs.   The extended version has some good instrumental pieces that the original doesn't have.  As for the other songs on the collection
column16: I wouldn't do handstands for them.  This collection has a horrible set of liner notes.   All that is contained inside the liner notes is a list of the songs.  The dates and producers of the songs are listed
column17: but there is nothing that credits the album that the song is from.   The center of the liner notes contain black and white photos of the four album covers.   That is basically it.   There is nothing else.  No instrumental credits
column18: no songwriting credits - the members of the band are not even listed.     It would have been nice to have a small writeup about the band.   All in all
column19: while it does a nice job at putting a collection of the songs - this disappoints me
column20: but more from the perspective of the band.  You still may want to check this out if you really love the band.

column6: "recao"
column7: saffron

column7: popularized in a Hollywood film (coincidentally?) only a year before "Play It"'s publication.  A minor footnote to a still-evolving trend

column1: Mandy
column2: Mandy
column3: Mandy.  This debut album from the versatile Broadway (Sunday in the Park with George) and Movie (The Princess Bride) star might shock you
column4: and so may this review.  Mr Patinkin's range is exceptional
column5: and the way he floats with ease into his upper-register is breath-taking.  His falsetto!  Stunning!  His emoting!  Stunning!  This solo debut!  Stunning!  By that
column6: I mean that I was stunned by this solo debut.  Mr Patinkin has the bloodiest sleeve in the industry with this album.  Take a listen to it
column7: but be warned; you just may cringe from the amount of open heart running down his sleeve
column8: because there's a lot of it
column9: and it's free-flowing.   He introduces us to his emotional state of mind with "Over the Rainbow" the standard that to this day has never been done better than by Ms Judy Garland
column10: post-Oz.  It's a nice rendition of it
column11: but you can hear him almost congratulating himself for having such a beautiful voice.  In my mind
column12: I envision his voice on the ceiling of the room with Patinkin reaching towards the ceiling trying to make love to it
column13: literally wrapping his body around it
column14: coiling in it and then popping out every now and then as if arising from extasy with a hefty
column15: sigh of passion.  And this takes the fun out of his performance.  I thought that this would be kept minimal on this CD.  I was wrong.  Arriving at Sondheim's "Pretty Lady
column16: I realized that he's very much in love with his voice.  He loves it so much that he uses it as 3 different people, overlapping in harmony.  This is one of the most memorable numbers from Pacific Overtures, and I liked the Original Broadway Cast version much better.  He did, however, keep his emoting to a minimum on this track.  Then it hit me.  Full force.  I could hear the opening of the Sondheim standard, No More."  I love this song.  It is my favorite song in "Into the Woods."  In the show
column17: it's a song about greed
column18: running away from your problems
column19: loss
column20: and generally breaks my heart everytime I see the show
column21: or listen to the never-outdone Original Broadway Cast recording.  It's about yearning and hoping
column22: and even a loss of hope.  Mandy Patinkin ruined this song.  I'm not going to paint a pretty picture about what he did to this song
column23: but it is awful.  His emoting is like a brick wall of hearts thrown at my face.  The laughing at the end of phrases is so planned and intentional that it brings to mind the word "pretention."  This is such a tender song occurring soon after the Baker's Wife is killed.  And Mandy Patinkin is laughing.  What kind of interpretation is that?  It made my skin crawl.   The thing about Mr Patinkin is this:  He is a fantastic character actor with a phenomenal voice.  He just needs a director to reign him in.  For when left to his own devices
column24: he relishes in his voice and forgets that someone has to listen to him
column25: someone who maybe wore white that day and didn't want blood on their sleeve.

column1: Yeah and if you thought the review's title was ridiculous...  It's not so much that the book is confusing or that the characters could use a bit more depth
column2: it's that from the get-go
column3: the writing is cliche.  Pat Cadigan
column4: who hit a home run with Mind Players
column5: tries way too hard to be -- captial "C" -- Cyberpunk in this book.  It's possible that because I've only just read Synners while I read my first 'cyberpunk' book in the early 90s I've lost the ability to be impressed by attempts at 'hard edged' writing that tries to use slang like 'stone home' and 'hot-wire' to indicate a machine or drug centric society on the edge of destruction; but there's just so many sentences that seem oh so dutifully crafted to fit into what cyberpunk is Supposed To Be.    I give it two stars because underneath the cliche there are interesting ideas; it's just too bad one has to wade through so much over-eager writing to see them through.  If you really want to read an engaging book of speculative fiction by Pat Cadigan that bucks the cliches of cyberpunk and strikes out on its own read Mind Players

column1: Whatever felicity Edwards manages in this work
column2: do not credit the ideas represented to Edwards himself.  All of his central points on freedom are no more than a Christian appropriation of secular English philosophy in Hobbes
column3: somewhat in Locke
column4: and certainly of David Hume.  In the old philosophy
column5: choice is an illusion
column6: because in any course of action we are determined necessarily by our nature; Edwards agrees fully
column7: adding only that our nature gets some extra help from God when it comes to sanctification.      He advances the idea that in every snapshot of human life
column8: we make decisions in accordance with our nature and disposition.  Free will is compatabilist in that we have no autonomy other than to follow our greatest desire in any given instance.  Not only does this exposition rule out the chance for true virtue--some good thing we do which we might not have done--but Edwards also has a hard time explaining how God is not the author of evil
column9: given that human decisions are consistently determined according to a divine decree

column1: Cold Mountain is an unfortunate novel.  It is unfortunate it won the National Book award (why did it win?).  The novel has an unfortunate structure; Fraser simply strings along one incident after another
column2: with little connecting thread.  The weight of flashbacks alone drags the novel to the ground (and it hardly gets off the ground in the first place!)  There are glaring anachronisms.  It is difficult to believe that some of the sentiments he puts in his characters mouths could have been uttered in 1864.  This is a forgivable sin
column3: if the novel is well written
column4: if it rises about the banal
column5: if it offers something more than surface.  But this novel is all surfaces and all banality.  Its publication is indicative of some of the pathology of today's publishing world (this will be a BIG novel
column6: this will become a BIGGER film
column7: which will sell more of this BIG novel).  Too bad for us the novel does not justify the claims of its promoters.  Fraser's eight million dollar advance for his next work is probably a clarion signal of another BIG novel to come

column1: THIS REVIEW IS ABOUT THIS PUBLISHERS EDITION NOT ABOUT THE BOOKS CONTENT ITSELF.  If you want to know about the content--- be aware that this book is copyright free and in the public domain and you can actually read the entire text free
column2: online
column3: if you are curious about the content of the book and what it is about. I am a person who prefers a real
column4: bound book in the hand to reading on the computer screen or printing off a book onto computer paper.  I learned about this book as it is popular with homeschoolers using the Charlotte Mason method.  This book weaves science content into a story format (narrative format).  About this edition of the book--buyer beware!  I am very annoyed. I saw that Amazon sells three different publishers' versions of reprints of this very old book
column5: before I purchased the book from Amazon.  Of course I am mad at myself for making a mistake
column6: but I am also not happy with the way Amazon markets this Kessinger Publishing's version of this book.  I have had issues in the past with facsimile reprints of antique books sometimes being very hard to read. I took time to research this. I wanted whichever publisher's version has a readable font that is clearly printed.  The way Amazon presently has this item (book reprinted by Kessinger Publishing) set up on their webpage
column7: I thought I was looking inside this book. Imagine my surprise when the book arrived and the printing itself is horrible! I can't stand to read this! Upon double checking this now
column8: I see I made a simple mistake--if you don't want to make the same mistake that I made please read on...  It appears that this Kessinger Publishing version is a facsimile reproduction of the original. The old font type is hard to read. But the more problematic thing is that the ink is blobby and uneven. Specifically
column9: I mean that some parts of the letters are missing (there is white space) while others are blobbed so that the letters don't look as they should
column10: they are black blobs in some parts. I would prefer a book whose text is clearly visible. A modern font is also usually easier on the eyes.  I am very annoyed as this is not even the cheapest price edition of this book which is currently in print! Come to find out there are cheaper versions with nicer and easier to read font!  I am upset with Amazon additionally as the way they have this set up to "look inside this book" brings you to the edition published by the publisher "Yesterday's Classics" which has what looks to be a great font
column11: a nice
column12: clear
column13: modern font and a good printing job. (Also today I received a different book purchased from Amazon by the publisher "Yesterday's Classics" and it is a wonderful printing job and a a nice binding to boot.  I will be returning this book to Amazon. Too bad I have to pay the shipping to return it to them!

column1: The prose in this book is so convoluted and each point takes so long to develop that you'll be soon asleep.   What's worse
column2: the book is neither a solid academic overview of the field nor is it a useful handbook for the practitioner.    Rossi and his co-authors make many attempts to give us the grand theoretical frameworks but they quickly get lost in qualifying themselves into a tepid soup in which nothing is ever black or white
column3: hot or cold
column4: true or false.     Although there are some capsule summaries and references to real programmes
column5: these callouts are helpful only to break the tedium.  They are not presented in sufficient detail that normal people could ever learn from them.  There is never any clear instruction about how one should begin an evaluation or how one should proceed.    Possibly this book is useful for an intermediate-to-advanced evaluation practitioner who is interested in comparing his broad generalizations with Rossi's.

column1: Over the years I've learned to beware of writers who earn their living inside the walls of academe. It's often a creative trap
column2: and Ms. Moore is no exception. She shows all the shortcomings of a scribe who uses her students as bouncing boards for vignettes
column3: none of which deal with people very far from university life and none of which are in any real sense true short stories. The "in" jokes among her often stereotypical characters may amuse freshmen writing majors
column4: but the average reader looks in vain for any true authenticity (as
column5: for example in the stories of Alice Munro or T.C. Boyle). The shame of it is that Ms. Moore can write--but in this collection she chooses to offer us nothing that holds any attention beyond a clever sentence

column1: ...upon actual research it is clearly false. Many others have delved into the finer points of Menzies' poor methodology and often deliberate exaggeration or falsities
column2: so I won't bother. I'll only list four points that I think stand out even without deep fact checking:  1)Niccolo di Conti
column3: the venetian explorer and crucial link in the book who supposedly sailed with the Chinese treasure fleet in 1421
column4: failed to mention in his memoirs anything about Chinese junks or going to the four corners of the world. This seems strange.  2)The Fleet sailed to virtually every coastline in the world but missed Europe entirely
column5: the one place sure to mark their passing for posterity. This is neither evidence nor disproof
column6: merely a sketchy coincidence.  3)Native Americans are given startlingly short shrift
column7: both in the book and in many of the reviews. Virtually every time something sophisticated is presented in the ancient new world it is attributed to the Chinese
column8: reminding me of the Easter Island "mystery" of who carved those giant heads. For the record
column9: Native populations weren't childish savages; prior to European contact they had very sophisticated civilizations
column10: fully capable of jewelery work
column11: cloth garments
column12: and carving statues.  4)Lastly
column13: Given the vast numbers of Chinese sailors involved(roughly 25-30
column15: the presence of domesticated animals such as horses and pigs
column16: and the inevitable presence of huge numbers of stow-away rats
column17: doesn't it strike anyone as odd that there were apparently no diseases passed on to the various native populations in the Americas? It only took a very small amount of European contact to spark the largest
column18: and deadliest pandemic in history that raged for nearly two centuries killing unknown millions of Native Americans. Chinese contact of the scale claimed would certainly have had a similar
column19: if not worse
column20: effect.  Ultimately Menzies' book is entertaining
column21: leaving the reader hoping it is true merely for the fantastic nature of the thesis. In the end
column22: however
column23: the evidence and analysis simply are not there.

column3: Scooby and the gang have car trouble in a desert. Fred

I won't deny that there are some good moments in this movie. (For undoubtedly the first time, Scooby and Shaggy go to a restaurant and want nothing!) Thank goodness for the eventual Legend of the Vampire" and "Aloha Scooby Doo."

column1: Am I the *ONLY* person who thinks Thoreau was an arrogant snob who did nothing but whine? Maybe it's because I'm an Englishman in America but all I hear is American educational institutions praising Thoreau's "Civil Disobedience". I don't deny that he has made some points worth considering in his book but many people have made the same points without whining and railing at humanity.  I would dearly like to say I had the patience to read this book all the way through but it is perhaps the only book I've ever read that I couldn't finish. I found it hard to separate Thoreau's genuine
column2: honest observations from his juvenile complaining.   The phrase that most ran through my head (shortly before I deleted the book) was "o'erweening arrogance". The man's arrogance is astounding. He supposes himself so far superior to his peers in EVERY way.  I found his writing to be confused and self-serving. He could barely hold a topic for one page at a time before veering off on to another
column3: entirely unrelated one. He skips from subject to subject and often contradicts himself within the same chapter.  I got the electronic version of this book and
column4: to date
column5: it is the only book I have actually deleted. So
column6: I'd love to pepper my "critique" with quotes that I found completely offensive and juvenile but that would mean getting the book again and I *really* don't want to do that

column1: This novel is totally "stream of consciousness."  It jumps around through past and present.  It's impossible to follow any kind of coherent plot.  I had enjoyed the movie "LA Confidential" and thought I wanted to read Ellroy.  I was mistaken!
Overall
column2: I wouldn't recommend the Insider's Guide to the Colleges to either parents or students.  I feel that Fiske
column3: Princeton Review and Kaplan (even though the last edition is becoming dated) are better sources of information.    However
column4: there are some good aspects to the Insider's Guide so I would at least recommend picking up the book at the library and skimming the beginning section on choosing a college.  Insider's does a good job of mentioning all the facets a student should consider and they do a very fair job of detailing the strengths and weaknesses of both small and large schools.  On the other hand
column5: I have to agree with the reviewer who said that the entries make each school sound like either a "party school" or a "nerd school" as if colleges only came in two varieties.  I think it quickly becomes very hard to distinguish individual qualities of the schools because so much emphasis is placed on the balance of partying to studying to the exclusion of other information
column6: particularly about good academic reasons to attend a school.  It's also apparent that Insider's is placing a little too much emphasis on sports when they discuss a school's croquet or handball program.  Yep
column7: that makes the school different
column8: but it should be obvious to Insider's that there are other aspects of the school they should have focused on instead.   Now my writing is not the best
column9: but I suppose I expected better from Yale students.  One writer used the non-existent word "irregardless" (it's "regardless") while another couldn't be bothered to check if Stony Brook was one word or two.  The writers sometimes delivered badly executed last paragraphs with incongruous sentences
column10: poor transitions and confusing conclusions.  You end up with something like "Students at X University say that the food is horrific
column11: the dorms should be condemned and the school is less exciting than a cemetery.  It's a great place to spend four years."  Yes
column12: I suppose it would be fair to give them a break since they're only undergraduates (I think)
column13: but I feel it's important to expose our high school kids to the superior writing found in other guides like Fiske or Princeton Review instead of something that's not very good.    This brings me to the Insider's Guide's assertion that the book is "funny and incredibly entertaining."  While this is subjective
column14: I strongly disagree.  The Insider's Guide is fairly boring compared to the much wittier Princeton Review guide.  Personally
column15: my favorite is Fiske
column16: but I would say that if a parent is having trouble getting her teenager to start looking at colleges seriously
column17: she'd pick up something besides Fiske
column18: and I suspect it's often the Insider's Guide as it's written by "students for students."  However
column19: not only is Princeton Review better written
column20: the format of the Insider's Guide is user-surly with small print and cramped
column21: unattractive pages.  I will say that the Insider's Guide does a better job of sticking to factual statistics than giving schools subjective ratings on a four-star scale
column22: and some may prefer that.  As a matter of fact
column23: the Insider's Guide does have a few statistics that Princeton Review neglects and two of them are important:  The freshman retention rate and the graduation rate.  Both statistics are fairly good indicators of how happy students are at their respective schools.  So if those stats are important to you
column24: that might be one reason to at least browse through the Insider's Guide.    The Insider's Guide inexplicably leaves out some top-notch schools
column25: particularly in Texas and Louisiana (such as Loyola) while including some rather absurd choices that have SAT means in the low 400's or in one case
column26: 300's.  They also have a number of large state schools that I don't feel have any place in a guide to the "top schools."  The fact is that they attract a multitude of applicants which means more people will buy this book.   I wouldn't suggest removing the schools with very unimpressive statistics if there are sufficient reasons to keep them (in many cases
column27: I couldn't find any)
column28: but with some  incomprehensible exclusions
column29: I can't say I find the book authoritative or comprehensive.  Go with Fiske or
column30: if your student isn't excited about researching colleges
column31: go with Princeton Review.

column1: I purchased this Vantec product and used it for a short time.  Most USB enclosures offer "heat dissipation thru the metal case"
column2: as does this one. However
column3: I grew very concerned about how hot the Vantec became
column4: especially after active operation.   Heat is a major enemy of electrical motors. The HDD obviously just cooks inside the Vantec. There is also a definitive  difference between its temperature in stand-by mode
column5: and during/immediately after active use.   I found another USB enclosure offering active ventilation: the Apricorn EZ Bus DT
column6: which not only has a built-in fan
column7: but IMHO
column8: for several critical reasons
column9: is a better design and a smarter choice.  Here is why:   The Apricorn's 3-inch diameter fan is mounted transversely
column10: so it pulls heat directly off the entire underside of the HDD and expels thru vents on either end of the case.   In comparison
column11: the Vantec's internal chassis has a solid metal plate which covers the entire HDD circuit board (see the image I loaded above).  The Vantec has no venting
column12: so the heat inside builds up fast. I installed a 500GB HDD in the Apricorn and ran a 220+GB backup from the Vantec. Upon completion hours later
column13: the Apricorn's exterior was completely cool to the touch; the Vantec's exterior was REALLY HOT.  A couple of other things I found superior about the Apricorn:   It's heavier with a wider base
column14: compared to the Vantec's (3" vs. 1.5"). When mounted vertically
column15: you can nudge the Vantec (or the desk it's sitting on) and it will fall over; it happened twice in the few days I used it. There would be major motion required to tip the Apricorn
column16: and I've never toppled it in months of use.   The Apricorn's easy-action pushbutton power switch is conveniently (and sensibly) located on the front of the unit. The Vantec's is on the bottom of the rear panel (see photo above)
column17: but it's a stiff toggle-type switch and awkward to operate. You have to hold the Vantec down with one hand firmly in order to get enough leverage to operate the balky switch... and you leave a nice handprint on the case
column18: which then has to be cleaned. Do that a few times and the sexy "mirror finish" isn't going to look new for very long.   Also
column19: the Vantec's internal PC board HDD cable is mounted off-center on from the socket on any HDD. You have to kink the Vantec's flat cable in order to complete the connection (see photo above). The Apricorn's is located exactly in line with the HDD's connector
column20: and requires no stressing of the cable.   The Apricorn is available here on Amazon
column21: but I found it for less at Page Computers. It is slightly higher in cost than the Vantec
column22: but I'm convinced it is a much better product. Also
column23: with Apricorn's active ventilation and greater physical stability
column24: I have peace of mind about the longevity & safety of the expensive drive mounted inside it

column1: Every so often
column2: Thomas Bezucha`s "The Family Stone"  injects itself with a dose of reality about the modern liberal family - that intellectual
column3: caustic
column4: "progressive

column10: but not sincere. It is a Christmas family mosaic where everybody gathers round the twelve-seat dining table of a nine-bedroom house for a seven-course meal to assume their roles and pick on The Prodigal Son's new girlfriend. It is also a button-pushing
column11: shameless picture that insists we like that shrill
column12: pushy Diane Keaton persona more or less because her character is dying of cancer. Keaton plays one of those "full of it" moms - falsely hip
column13: falsely sage
column14: constantly yelling and hugging and pitching fits and hogging the stage - so accustomed  is she to this domestic tyranny that when the girlfriend calls her on it
column15: we get a scene I couldn`t quite believe.   Back to that in a minute. "The Family Stone" assembles a large cast for its tale: Keaton is Sybil; Craig T. Nelson is husband Kelly; Dermot Mulroney is the parent-pleaser Everett
column16: Luke Wilson is the laid-back  Ben; Ty Giordano is the gay
column17: deaf Thad. And Rachel McAdams slums (just a little) as mommy's academic daughter Amy
column18: who sincerely (yet inexplicably) dislikes Everett's  straight-laced fiance Meredith (Sarah Jessica Parker) as much she will eventually like Meredith's sister Julie (Claire Danes)
column19: who arrives midway through and enraptures Everett
column20: who`s 16 years older.   "She does this thing with her throat
column21: Amy says of Meredith's phlegm-clearing tic. Meredith cannot  relax, and the Stones' idea of hospitality is to let their guest know how hospitable they could be - if only she would make herself at home. Sybil and Amy take their snarky turns on Meredith. Sybil stares wistfully out the window awaiting the mid-movie revelation that she's dying. Mulroney puts on his Mulroney Face - think Stallone in mild anguish - while Everett wrestles with it all. Kelly and Ben eat marijuana brownies at the high school football field. Ben looks at Meredith as if he'd like to see if she loosens up drunk. Three potato chips if you've guessed she loosens up drunk.  It leads to and falls away from that moment at the dinner table when Ty's homosexuality is thrown around for some tired, liberal humor. Ty and his boyfriend (Brian White) intend to adopt children, and Meredith asks a sincere question of nature vs. nurture, which Sybil bombastically turns into a mini-skit on how she wished all her sons had been gay, a plenty-ignorant thing to say, deliberately said for effect, which Meredith misses. Thus Meredith's second question: Do you really mean that?"  What Bezucha writes next is fascinating
column22: if brutal and unfair. The entire family dives into Meredith - it climaxes with Sybil literally cursing the girl to hell - while Ty
column23: a saint by now
column24: mists at the notion that maybe he
column25: a deaf
column26: gay man
column27: has had a life he may not have wished on his brothers. Meredith is a stiff and suit
column28: sure

That gays should adopt children? That blowhards are better than the sincere because they`re dying and judgmental in the right ways? That all can be forgiven with
column30: fittingly

column1: I'm a sucker for these "social satire" type novels
column2: especially when they skewer the rich pretentious people in New York City for whom only the Ivys are good enough and who start with the fierce competition in preschool.  This book sounded like it would deliver that
column3: but unfortunately
column4: it bored me.  I was never really clear on why Laura wanted to be involved in this mess in the first place.  She is presented as having good
column5: solid values
column6: but she gets caught up in the competition madness anyway.  Which she admits
column7: but then her claims to be somehow "better" or have "more common sense" than the other characters do not stand up to scrutiny.  But then there was the book itself...boring.  A major mystery revolves around who kills a hamster.  Could there be a sociopath-in-the-making
column8: some "evil" young child who is a hamster-murderer?  Which children attend therapy?  Could a child have some awful disorder that would make him or her do this?  Obviously
column9: since the hamster-killer will be rejected from the exclusive school
column10: it is imperative to find out just who wrung the hamster's neck
column11: and as soon as possible.  Competitive parents are trying to lock other children out of the prestigious school by falsely accusing other children of hamster-murder.  I mean
column12: come on.  Could this happen?  I suppose so.  Is it funny or satirical?  No.  It's not portrayed well enough to be funny
column13: and it's much too l-o-n-g and drawn out to be good satire.  I got really tired of hearing about the darned hamster.  Maybe the point is that these parents will freak out about everything
column14: but unfortunately
column15: the reader gets dragged through a bunch of "is it him?  is it her?  will my child be falsely accused?" hamster-murder BS until I was thoroughly sick of the whole thing.  It seems to me that good satire is not boring
column16: but boy
column17: is this preoccupation boring.  When we finally find out who killed the hamster and why
column18: I was completely underwhelmed.  I didn't care about anyone at that point.  Of course there are the requisite "secrets" about the upper-crust parents
column19: but I'm afraid they bored me as well.  I'm learning the hard way that just because a novel is described as satire
column20: and the situation sounds very interesting
column21: that does NOT make it good reading.  I'm having a similar struggle getting through Claire Messud's latest
column22: but I will try it again.    Satire should be interesting
column23: and the fact that so many authors fall back on the Candide device (wide-eyed innocent observing a bunch of weirdos) is getting extremely tiresome.  Especially when Candide compromises her principles to be part of the popular crowd and then has an unrealistic "revelation" at the end.  Please
column24: give me Edith Wharton any day over this

column1: ROBOT MONSTER is one of "those" classic Five Star One Star '50s horror movies. The problem with "C" movies is that they can't be rated by the usual standards. By its own standards its a gem.   But for the fact that this gobbler wasn't touched by Ed Wood it has all the guaranteed elements of bad moviemaking. Actually
column2: ROBOT MONSTER was panned so severely upon release that director Phil Tucker attempted suicide afterward.  ROBOT MONSTER concerns the depredations of a fat gorilla-suited space alien in a diving helmet (Ro-Man from the planet Ro-Man which is populated by the race of Ro-Mans) who comes to earth and destroys virtually all of human life with the aid of a vacuum tube radio and a Lawrence Welk bubble machine.  Ro-Man is a grouchy
column3: slow moving space visitor who talks with his hands and grumbles a lot. He lives in one of the more familiar Hollywood caves of Bronson Canyon
column4: California.   The few surviving humans (a family of five) protect themselves by stringing aluminum foil around their house so that Ro-Man cannot use his death ray machine against them. Instead
column5: he must dispose of them one at a time "by the process of strang-u-laaa-tion" if they are so foolish as to step outside of their Reynolds Wrap safety zone.    Given their current world political situation
column6: the humans
column7: Richard Nixon-like
column8: are seeking "Peace---But peace with honor!" from Ro-Man. Hmmm. Seems reasonable. After all
column9: Ro-Man has really shown restraint up until this point. Why shouldn't they trust him?    But wait! Even after atomizing everybody else (apparently including the film's scriptwriter) Ro-Man has developed a penchant for Alice
column10: the eldest daughter of the survivors. Fortunately for us
column11: Alice seems to have a corresponding yen for excessively hirsute and overweight men wearing fishbowls on their heads. So while Ro-Man is distracted picking a bouquet for his new girlfriend
column12: the family figures out a way to finally finish him off.    Exactly how humanity is going to repopulate the earth with only the Father Knows Best kids around escapes me
column13: but clearly someone involved with this film escaped from somewhere.  It's as bad and as much fun as it sounds.

column13: I'm immediately going to be freakin' suspicious.  Author Malcolm Gladwell tells us on the cover
