column1: This novel deserves 5 stars.  I was given 44 Scotland Street as a Christmas gift. I assumed it was a "detective story" given the author's previous well known work. I was very pleasantly surprised to find the book was like nothing else I have ever read.  I have lived in Scotland and have visited Jenner's department store in Edninburgh
column2: as well as some of the other landmarks mentioned in the book. I can assure readers who have not been to Edinburgh that the descriptions and the characterizations are very real
column3: for example
column4: the rivalry between Edinburgh and Glasgow.  Although it may be difficult for non-Scots to fully appreciate certain elements of the book
column5: the characters can be found practically anywhere and in any time. For example
column6: the narcissistic Bruce and the class-conscious Sasha. I would highly recommend this book to anyone and especially homesick Scots.  I can hardly wait for the sequel

column1: The guy is a liar...where I come from that doesn't add up to much.
In this fine work of literature
column2: Mr. Manovich illustrates that he can talk a lot about computers
column3: even though he doesn't know anything about them.  He makes a plethora of fallacious statements
column4: such as when he argues that all digital media must be discrete and contain only discrete objects
column5: neglecting one can define a continuous geometry using discrete coefficients.  If his statment were true
column6: there'd be no way to draw a circle in Adobe Illustrator
column7: but I know I've done that before!  Read this book if you don't know what a computer is and won't mind misinformation presented to prove points that are stupid and worthless anyway

column1: 1998's "Lost in Space" is just a mediocre sci-fi movie that's full of plot devices we've already seen in droves of other sci-fi outings.  Nothing new here. But this movie only seemed to be made as a marketing ploy to sell toys.  They didn't even bother with a sequel
column2: and the movie ended with a strong hint that there would be.  They really need to stop dusting off old TV shows for movie ideas

column8: and held my interest enough so that
column9: unlike Impossible
column10: I actually finished it in one day.  The bad news is that this book seems entirely devoid of any attempt at editing.  The repetition is maddening. When reading becomes a chore

column16: I wanted to pull my hair out.  Small thing

column18: DS needs a good editor. This book could have been one of her best to date.

This is the worst sociology book I have ever read
column2: a complete disservice to the stuggle for women's equality and an embarrassment to the university which trained its author and to the press which published it. I was one of the subjects interviewed by the author. Her methods are flawed: she failed to interview both men and women working for the same institution
column3: rather than simply in the same profession
column4: making everything the men told her about their jobs worthless as scientific data. Her analysis is suspect: she didn't publish the full text of her interviews
column5: but simply selected statements
column6: leaving the reader no way to fairly judge the context or overall tone of the subjects
column7: or judge whether these quoted responses were typical or unusual. Her conclusions are laughable: she found that men either seek promotion or do not. Men seek promotion in order to dominate and control women;  men decline promotion because they secretly despise the women they work with. It's too bad such an interesting and important subject could not be dealt with in a scientific way

column1: Let me begin by saying this book sucked.  It sucked so hard
column2: I'm suprised black holes aren't springing up near it.  I only finished this book because I bought it and thought it would be wrong of me not to. (I only actually "read" about half of it
column3: the rest I read on skim mode)  The writing was uninspired and I didn't understand the heroine.  At all.  She was apparently some wealthy New Orleans socialite who always dreamt of being a wife and mother.  But she didn't actually take care of her child.  Or clean her house.  Or have sex with her husband (he was having an affair with a fellow lawyer and was tragically killed in a car accident.)  I have no idea WHAT this woman did all day.  Except maybe eat icecream?  There were several scenes that annoyed me
column4: but I think the worse was when Jonnie (Her name was Jonquil
column5: which PLEASE.) decided she was tired of her late husband's study being dark so she pulls out a chair and rips down the drapes.  Where she leaves them piled on the floor until he maid comes into the room to see what's going on.  Jonnie promptly tells the maid to dispose of the drapes.  Does Jonnie have something pressing to do?  Could she not clean up the mess she made?  After that; I just sort of hated her and hoped she was hit by a bus.  I didn't much care for the hero
column6: Cameron
column7: either.  He seemed very one dimensional and like every other romance novel bad boy.  He was in trouble as a juvenile
column8: yet he was really tender and sensative.  I will say that through his actions I had a better feel for his compassion and concern for others.  So
column9: I guess that's a plus.  With Jonnie
column10: I felt like the reader was always being told what to think of her.  You should think Jonnie is compassionate because she hired a nanny David (the dead husband) wouldn't have given her a chance.  You should think Jonnie wants to take care of her child because she says so (even though Jonnie leaves her daughter alone or with the nanny most of the to run off and be with Cameron.)  I never understood the title of the book either.  I still can't figure out what is opposite about the characters
column11: and their attraction was tepid at best.  I don't recommend this book
column12: unless you're stranded on an island alone and might go crazy with the boredom.  But even then
column13: I would try coconut sculpture first

column1: At first I thought it was great. The cat likes it and loves to watch it clear itself. Now the cat uses it to poo but not to pee. There is way!!! to much cat litter. When it cleans itself it trys to pulls half the cat litter into the SMALL cardboard tray. I still have to clean the box once a week which I guess is better than three times a day. I guess our cat poos a lot. The poo does get stuck in the prongs from time to time and that is your que to clean the tray out. I also don't like that the cat really shuffles the litter around before he goes so it sets the sensor off and we have to shake the box often or just push the button to get it to run. That is kind of anoying. I think they really need to make some adjustments to the box but if you have an older cat that doesn't dig a lot or poop a lot then this is the box for you. Be aware though you will most likely have to clean it every week. I had to actually flip the lid around so the cat would push the litter away from the tray. He was helping push the litter into the tray so it would fill up clean litter and the poop would get stuck in the grid. All in all it's not to bad!

column2: by the time the story has completely unfolded

I have recently started reading James Patterson.  I have quickly come to enjoy his work on the Alex Cross series.  That's why I chose to try this book.  What a mistake!  I could not get over the fact that Patterson was attempting some form of cross between mystery and science fiction.  Obvious potential storyline (what happens to the parents of the children?) was lost for tiring character development.  It takes way too long for the villan of the story to come forward and actually play a part.  Then
column2: when he does
column3: not much happens.  It felt as though a quarter of the book was spent developing the feelings of two characters towards eachother and then maybe 5 chapters (out of over 100) spent resolving the problem.  Due to the excitement I have had in reading the Alex Cross novels
column4: I felt it was difficult putting this book down.  Burning eyes and constant yawning fought me as I tried to search for something to happen.  Once it did
column5: it was over.  I have never been so glad to complete a book and put it away.  I hope James Patterson does not venture down this path again

column1: Michael Gondry has followed "The Eternal Sunshine of the Spotless Mind" with "The Science of Sleep."  Unfortunately
column2: the film spends more energy on the fantastic way it tells the story than on telling a story.  In short
column3: we go through all these dreamlike images of hands that suddenly become huge
column4: a dancing donkey or Bernal flying over a claymation-like cityscape
column5: but that don't further the story.  As an actor
column6: Gael Garcia Bernal is such a nice looking young guy that you seem to want to root for him.  However
column7: he became increasingly strange and unlikable as the film went on.  Bernal won the Best Supporting Actor Award from the French Academy of Cinema in 1999 for "La Buche" and was impressive in "The Motorcycle Diaries."  As Stephane
column8: he's more neurotic.  Sometimes it's hard to tell if he's asleep or awake; or in which world the big change in his life is supposed to happen.  Apparently
column9: that change is supposed to be that he falls in love.  The film teases romance with Stephanie who lives across the hall.  I think we have the male Stephane and the female Stephanie's names selected to show a kindred spirit connection
column10: but it becomes a bit confusing such as the film being spoken in Spanish
column11: French and English intermittently.  Emma De Cannes who will be in "Mr. Bean's Holiday" this year plays Stephanie's friend Zoe to who Stephane is attracted.  This is an odd complication since it's never clear which girl Stephane wants; and he seems never to be able to make a decision.  Then you have Alain Chabat as the obnoxious Guy showing up at work and in bars with his one-track mind.  Chabat was nominated for the French Academy of Cinema's Best Supporting Actor award in 2000 for "The Taste of Others
column12:
but it's hard to see why with this one-note role and performance.  Overall, the film doesn't go anywhere.  Yes, it does make creative use of fantasy and absurd cinematic elements, but unfortunately they don't serve to tell a story.  At the end, I was glad the film was finally over.  Taxi

column1: This is an eminently Catholic book written by a sinner in his young age
column2: becoming a singer of the heavenly pleasures of asceticism
column3: growing older. It is a long masochistic call to God for forgiveness of his previous sins in order to get eternal bliss.  Saint Augustine sees sins everywhere and every time. Every newborn baby receives a stamp `original sin' from his first day on earth
column4: followed immediately by `Was it a sin to cry when I wanted to be feed at the breast?' All organs are sources of sin: the ears
column5: the eye
column6: the smell
column7: taste (eating and drinking) and obsessively
column8: sex (`better a eunuch for love of the kingdom of heaven'). The bodily pleasures leave him so terrified to loose eternal bliss that `Even in my sleep I resist the attractions'! Other characteristic cardinal Christian rules are: obey all authorities (`In his own kingdom a king has the right to make orders')
column9: censure (`But your law
column10: God
column11: permits the free flow of curiosity to be stemmed')
column12: and deep anti-science sentiments (`futile curiosities masquerade under the name of science and learning. The secrets of nature are irrelevant to our lives.')  One should think that `love thy neighbor' is one of his basic principle. Absolutely not. He is a profound sectarian: `the Manichees
column13: I ought to have disgorged these men like vomit.' But
column14: why is he so sure that he is right? Because of his faith (`not a clear view')
column15: his faith in God and the Holy Scriptures. Saint Augustine's Confessions contain also rather childish reflections on the mind
column16: the body-mind dichotomy
column17: memory and
column18: e.g.
column19: `the problem of space and God's dimensions'.  But not everything is negative in this book. There is the love for his mother and his young son. Remarkable is his vision that time didn't exist before the creation of the universe. As a former sinner
column20: Saint Augustine knows human nature all too well; e.g. `Men love truth when it bathes them in its light; they hate it when it proves them wrong.' More importantly
column21: he found a religious solution for the problem of evil: if God created everything
column22: he is also responsible for all evil in the world. But God gave all human beings a free will. Every human being is individually responsible for his actions. (This is not the case for Calvin's creed of predestination). One should in no way underestimate Saint Augustine's influence on Christian and Western morals. Only for historians and theologians.

column1: I have been a design student for about two years and I purchased this book soley through word of mouth.  I approached this book as if I was a beginner
column2: knowing that the book was intended for such readers.  However
column3: as I read through the pages and completed most of the exercises
column4: I realized that if I had been a true novice
column5: that this book would have been extremely difficult to understand and very frustrating.  In sections such as dividing a square
column6: the author unclearly explains how to find the center of a square by drawing its diagonals
column7: but fails to explain how to find the midpoints of the sides
column8: and instead
column9: assumes that you already know how to do so.  The exercises are the worst part of this book.  Like a beginner
column10: I performed each exercise according to the author's instructions.  However
column11: I always ended up with distorted images.  An example is when the author asks you to duplicate a cube in each direction.  Unless you are a machine
column12: your cube will not be perfect and your duplicated cubes would only come out distorted.  But that is why a cube is already provided for you in the book for you to work on.  However
column13: it seems that even professionals are imperfect
column14: for when you duplicate the cube which is provided in the book
column15: you still end up with distorted cubes.  As a beginner I would have been extremely frustrated.  I even asked one of my instructors to see if she could perform the exercise and she ended up with distorted  cubes as well.  Not only were the exercises frustratingly difficult
column16: but the book's soft covers did not make it a suitable workbook.  Most of the time you're asked to work from off the sketces in the book
column17: but the pages are constantly bending as you're sketching in it
column18: and the illustrator's sketches are not very accurate in terms of perspective and scale.  I gave this book 2 stars because it does indeed mention good points when it comes to design
column19: such as visual thinking
column20: perspective
column21: the "box method"
column22: and lettering.  But those points are not thoroughly explained enough and the exercises are terribly presented especially for a novice designer

column1: I felt this was a highly disappointing and unsatisfactory book about an 8-year-old child who has autism. Kristy
column2: the 13-year-old protagonist in this story baby sits Susan
column3: whose autism is so severe that she does not communicate meaningfully. She has an extraordinary gift for music and can reproduce any song she hears on the piano. She does not play or interact with others.   Other kids soon learn of Susan's musical prowess and charge admission to hear her play. They exploit her talents until Kristy intervenes. Susan can also provide any given date and her mother explains that Susan once saw a perpetual calendar which sparked this interest.   Parts of the book reflected antiquated attitudes and misperceptions about autism. Kristy looks the word up in the dictionary and the definition provided was that it is a form of schizophrenia or withdrawal from reality. Autism is NOT schizophrenia and people with autism don't necessarily "withdraw from reality." Indeed
column4: people with autism often feel bombarded with outside stimuli and develop coping mechanisms to "come even
column5: that is to tone down the sensory onslaught that is so much a part of the autism experience. Suggesting that autism is in any way, shape and form related to schizophrenia has proved very costly to people with autism. Sadly, this kind of thing has caused many people with autism to be misdiagnosed. This in turn has led to many inappropriate treatments and placements being inflicted on people with autism! This kind of thing does not help anybody and has harmed many.   This book is not meant to be a diagnostic tool, but I wish autism had been defined in a more accurate way.  Rest assured, autism is NOT a disease but a neurobiological condition that affects sensory integration and communication based on the individual.  I for one am good and tired of seeing characters with autism being portrayed as having savant abilities. That only applies to roughly less than 10% of the autistic population and I can't help but wonder if this story just reinforces those stereotypes of people with autism to the neurotypical population. Same old tired tune, just a different performer.   To the author's credit, no promises are made. Susan is by the close of the story enrolled in a residential program for autistic children. I did feel the story was extremely weak. I also wondered why Susan was sent to a residential school as opposed to a day program in her area.   Read Ann M. Martin's Inside Out" instead. That is a much better book by this author about a child who has autism.  At least James is a Beatles' fan

column1: I didn't make it the whole way through this densely written and intimidating book
column2: but I was absorbed by one aspect: its portrayal of the human interaction between Marx and Engels.   Karl Marx was a psychologically warped semi-genius who continually begged money and favors from his hardworking and enabling friend Friedrich Engels. Sometimes Marx would agree to write articles or essays that he couldn't produce - he manipulated Engels into ghostwriting
column3: and still collected the pay himself.  I also found it interesting that Engels developed his ideas on the class system while he was in England
column4: observing the human experience in industrialized Manchester
column5: which was at that time economically depressed and in a state of social unrest
column6: with a great disparity between the factory owners and workers.  Marx and Engels wrote each other numerous multi-language letters over the years
column7: and _To the Finland Station_ does a nice job tracing this correspondence. It was interesting to learn that spreading their doctrine into Russia was sort of an incidental afterthought
column8: but  I'm afraid I could not bring myself to sift through the intricacies of the development of socialism/communism.     This is a weighty book
column9: and will not be of interest to every reader

I was disappointed in the latest Lincoln Rhyme mystery. The book had more twists than a Chubby Checker song and in the end they strained credibility.  Rhyme and Sachs are called in to solve a string of murders by a serial killer calling himself the Watchmaker. Rhyme has met his match with the Watchmaker
column2: a meticulous killer who leaves nothing to chance and leaves few clues for Rhyme to follow.  Running parallel to the story of the Watchmaker
column3: Sachs is also lead detective on her first case - a case that appears to involve police corruption. Sachs is juggling a heavy case load as well as rumours that her own father may have been corrupt. Ron Pulaski steps up to help with crime scenes and proves himself to be a smart and resourceful officer but ultimately it is up to Rhyme and Sachs to solve the case.   The book introduces Kathryn Dance
column4: a visiting Californian expert in Kinesics
column5: the study of body language. Dance helps interview suspects and witnesses and plays a role in solving the case. There is also a hint of romance with officer Sellitto which is ultimately left hanging. The information about Kinesics is interesting and Dance is a character that could have used more development.   The title of the book comes from a season in the lunar calendar
column6: which is also a time of death. The book also contains a lot of information about clocks and time courtesy of the Watchmaker. There was some fascinating information
column7: but at times the book was bogged down in historical details about clocks.  The book lurches from one plot twist to the next. At first it was exciting
column8: but after a while it became tedious. NOTHING was what it seemed. Further I found Rhyme less likeable in this book - grumpy
column9: bossy
column10: pedantic and sarcastic. The only hint of humanity was in his fear that he may lose Sachs.  At times I found the writing clumsy. Deaver uses cliched adjectives in his sentences to describes his characters
column11: such as
column12: "the handsome
column13: sardonic and impatient criminalist" I found it trite to describe Rhyme that way.   This book is not as good as earlier Rhyme mysteries.

column1: Mark Twain called the Book of Mormon "chloroform in print" and he wasn't kidding.  It is by far the most boring read I have encountered (I could barely get through it).  I am a woman of faith - faith in God and faith in Christ and I don't know how anyone could believe this rubbish.  PLEASE
column2: anyone who is taking this at all seriously - do some research on the church.  Ask some hard questions (you will likely get a rehearsed answer
column3: but it's worth a shot).    Joseph Smith was accused (and fined with a misdimeanor) of being a "glass looker" - hired by a man to help him find buried silver mines started and left behind by the Spanish. He would use "magic stones" that were placed in a hat to tell him where to find the location.  So convenient that he later found "gold plates" and used what he called the "Urim and Thum" (which
column4: by the way are actually gemstones that were carried by the High Priests of Israel in biblical times) to translate these plates (he describes them as stones he looked at in a hat).    There are SO many myths that are told by members of the church "most men were SO distraught at the thought of polygamy"
column5: the age issue of Joseph translating the Book of Mormon
column6: Joseph Smith's actual role in polygamy (which really should be called polandry - when a woman has more than one husband...  11 of Josephs 33 wives were actually married to other men first and then married to him
column7: having NEVER divorced the first husband - what's up with that???).. etc.. and the list goes on and on...  I am not disputing that Mormons take care of their own... that they are often kind people who have good hearts
column8: I think that is all wonderful and if you want to join their church for those reasons that's great! Just PLEASE do some homework first and don't just rely on the "power of prayer".  There is a reason that Utah is the [...] capital of the USA (I'm sure every one of those people "prayed" about that big business decision - it can OFTEN be mis-intrepreted).

column1: Bagemihl belongs to the genre of writers who write a great deal but convey very little.  His huge book is divided into two parts; the second part describes case studies of homosexual behaviors among several animal species
column2: and the first part provides what could-with great difficulty-be called an analysis of these reports.  Bagemihl groups sexual behavior in terms of five broad categories: courtship
column3: affection
column4: interactions involving mounting and genital contact
column5: pair-bonding
column6: and parenting activities.  Such broad categorization risks confounding social interactions with sexual behavior
column7: possibly leading one to mistakenly assume that a preference for specific social partners is a sexual preference for these partners.    Bagemihl alleges same-sex sexual partner preference in at least some individuals in over 50 bird and mammalian species
column8: based on five types of interactions: intersexual competition for same-sex sexual partners
column9: sexual interactions between the object of intersexual competition and a same-sex competitor
column10: repeated pair-bonding with same-sex individuals or repeated selection of same-sex sexual partners
column11: reuniting with same-sex partners following prolonged separations with opposite-sex individuals
column12: and engaging in sexual activity with same-sex individuals in the presence of opposite-sex individuals.  Whereas these criteria are consistent with a same-sex sexual partner preference
column13: none of them definitively prove a same-sex sexual partner preference
column14: and an examination of the examples presented by Bagemihl reveals that the majority of the cases of same-sex courtship
column15: mounting
column16: and genital contact can be explained without assuming a same-sex sexual partner preference [see P. L. Vasey
column17: Ann Rev Sex Res 13
column19: the large number of case studies cited by Bagemihl notwithstanding
column20: his book cannot be used to claim that homosexual behavior is widespread in the animal kingdom because Bagemihl's case studies are drawn from a less than miniscule non-random fraction of the millions of animal species out there.    Bagemihl
column21: failing to find themes behind homosexual behaviors among animals
column22: offers a concept of biological exuberance
column23: whereby homosexual behavior is pursued for pleasure and is a goal by itself that need not serve any purpose other than pleasure.  Whereas this may be true
column24: it is difficult to believe that this could be the result of normal developmental processes.  Even among humans where much heterosexual behavior is non-conceptive
column25: non-conceptive heterosexual behaviors typically occur as a prelude to or in conjunction with conceptive sexual behaviors.  Additionally
column26: the pleasure that accompanies orgasm not only prompts heterosexuals to repeatedly indulge in conceptive intercourse but also facilitates pair-bonding
column27: which would come in handy if an offspring results from the union. Bagemihl's thesis on homosexuality
column28: within a paradigm that he calls non-Darwinian biology
column29: is meaningless for species that are capable of sexual reproduction only.     On the other hand
column30: whereas Bagemihl fails to provide evidence for a same-sex sexual partner preference among the animal studies he cites
column31: it has been proven that homosexual behaviors and a same-sex sexual partner preference are natural (i.e.
column32: occur irrespective of human intervention) in some individuals in some breeds of some animal species.  However
column33: nobody
column34: let alone Bagemihl
column35: has shown that homosexual behaviors are normal in some animals
column36: i.e.
column37: result from development in accordance with design. Whereas the question of the normality of homosexual behaviors among some individuals of various animal species remains unanswered
column38: a considerable amount of information shows that human homosexuality results from abnormal development
column39: specifically prenatal developmental disturbances.  See a newly published book in this regard: "The Nature of Homosexuality: Vindication for Homosexual Activists and the Religious Right."

column1: Let me just say
column2: I'm not a Seattle scenester
column3: I'm not illiterate and I don't like the Lashes.  Sorry!  I found a copy of this EP in the used bin at my local record store so I thought I'd give it a spin - it was only a couple bucks.  Needless to say it's going back to the used bin.  Imitating the Strokes and the Killers is really played-out right now.  What's the point?  These songs are derivative with a capital "D".  The world doesn't need one more moody-looking band with perfectly styled hair doing an inferior version of what's already out there.  The music itself is almost passable but the lyrics are really DUMB!  It's like reading a 12 year-old girl's diary.  Even my friend said "It sounds like these guys are about one year too late."  The Lashes are so derivative and unoriginal I almost suspect they were "manufactured" to be popular.  Absolutely soulless.

column1: "The Last River - The Tragic Race for Shangri-la".......Tragic. Yes I'd agree that this book is tragic. Tragic that I bothered reading it.....tragic that I paid for it in order to read it.....tragic that Todd wasted his time writing it......tragic that I disliked it so much that I can be bothered writing a review. The warning should have come upon examination of the back of the dust jacket. "Advance praise for The Last River" it reads. In retrospect this means no one is prepared to recommend the book after they have read it. It seems that Todd had a vision of how big a book needs to be
column2: and went to great lengths to flesh out the story to reach his goal. So much of the content has so little relevancy to the story

column4: but is worth a read
column5: but on this book

column1: I am an Egyptologist who teaches an online course in Egyptian hieroglyphs to the general public. While this book is widely available
column2: don't let that fool you into thinking it is at all reliable. The one reason it is available is because it is out of copyright and the publishers can print it at will and reap all the profits without paying any royalties. If Egyptologists had any say over it
column3: the book would be banned
column4: as it is completely outdated and wasn't even considered a good book when it was first published nearly 100 years ago. When I first started studying Egyptian myself
column5: my instructor started off the class by writing "Budge" on the board and enclosing it in a circle with a slash through it. That's how bad this book is. In my courses

column7: and is written in a way that makes Egyptian comprehensible to the modern reader. It's infinitely better than Budge

column1: The unflattering picture of JFK on the cover of the original paperback edition of this book gives away the author's perspective.  The author tends to select anything he can find that is negative in order to demonize  Kennedy as a moral ingrate and ineffective leader. He also confuses a  sexual appetite with leadership abilities and qualities. One could place  judgement on Kennedy for these excesses
column2: but then one would need to do the  same for a whole array of leaders who had trysts during their lives. If  there is any truth
column3: it is perhaps that in the current climate of reporting
column4: Kennedy would have been exposed to the world. It is a question of how he  might have behaved knowing that the risks were immense. The writer truly  fails to give balance in this assassination- of-character biography. The  early biographies of Kennedy by his followers were homages to the fallen  leader but Reeves' biography does not have the balance or the intellectual  soundness of a comprehensive biography. We'll have to wait for a more  definitive biography by a respected historian who can give balance to the  talents
column5: hubris and human frailties of John F. Kennedy.  This book is an  example of how NOT to write a biography. It deserves space on shelves with  Kitty Kelly's books and the horrible biography of John Lennon. It has the  same sort of National Enquirer approach even if with a long bibliography.  Reminds me of Calvin of Calvin and Hobbes showing his school report and  highlighting the nice plastic binder as a measure of value when the report  itself is far from brilliant

column1: The argument here is laid down as follows: 1)  America is the dominant power and it is spreading its wings around the world. The world is angry about this and hates America. 2)  In order to appease the world America must change its policies to become more like the world.  The recipe here is like those in the 1930s who argued for appeasement based on the false assumption that democracy was dying and that Bolshevism and Nazism were the only alternatives
column2: and Nazism would triumph and therefore should be first 'understood' and then appeased.  In this book a standard academic argues that we must appease the world
column3: that we must seek to 'understand' genocide and the Sudan and that America must therefore never oppose genocide because those who commit genocide might hate America
column4: instead America must appease all reactionary genocidal regimes that suppress human rights
column5: from North Korea
column6: to Iran to Sudan.  Terrorists hate America therefore America must learn from the terrorists and invite them to craft American policy so that it is in line with their goals.  America must never defend freedom and minorities because that is unpopular
column7: instead America should side with the majority
column8: even if the majority is set upon world conquest and the killing of all Americans.  In short this is a recipe for national suicide.  American policy was not popular with Adolf Hitler or Josef Stalin
column9: and apparently not with Osama Bin Laden.  The ideas presented here is that America should have been more understanding of these monsters and that America should have crafter her policy to be in line with whatever the world majority believes.  Thus if the world is for bringing back slavery then America should support slavery. If the world is for genocide
column10: then genocide must be the policy.  An extraordinary argument
column11: showing that we have apparently learned nothing from history.  History should have taught us the opposite
column12: namely that the minority has generally been correct
column13: that the world worshipped Nazism and Communism
column14: and that the world was wrong.  America was right to oppose these mass manifestations of national hatred.    A sad critique.  Seth J. Frantzman

column1: I expected to find this book stimulating and informative
column2: but came away feeling that Dennett is vastly overrated and quite ordinary in his thought process
column3: logical skills
column4: and writing.  This book does not explain or offer a theory on -- as its title promises -- what consciousness is; it merely offers a lot of random observations on and stories about consciousness.  Dennett seems to start everything he writes somewhere in the middle of a conversation he has been having with himself; he doesn't know how to properly introduce a topic to the reader.  He begins the book not with an overview of his subject or a presentation of a thesis
column5: but with a chapter on hallucinations -- a very specific area of consciousness.  I indulged it with the expectation that it would provide an entry point into a broader argument he wished to advance; instead it was just the first in a random string of narratives.    I suggest that in lieu of Dennett's writings on consciousness
column6: one read John Searle or Robert Ornstein.  Or if you want an engaging
column7: conversational style of writing on the subject
column8: look into Oliver Sacks.

column1: **1/2  There's a strange sort of paradox at work in "Remember Me
column2: My Love
column3: an Italian film that seems to be operating under some bizarre inverse law of quantum physics.  For while the movie itself moves at a breakneck pace, hurtling from one scene to another with near-reckless abandon, we can't help noticing that the faster it goes, the slower it seems.  Perhaps, we simply wear ourselves out trying to keep up with it and it is this exhaustion factor that ultimately accounts for our restlessness and ennui.  Remember Me
column4: My Love" focuses on a family of four
column5: whose members haven't been getting along too well of late.  The parents
column6: Carlo and Giulia
column7: are both trying to find ways to cope with a bad case of middle aged crisis: he
column8: by rekindling a romance with a beautiful former flame
column9: and she
column10: by pursuing the career in acting she abandoned when she became a wife and mother.  Their children
column11: Valentina and Paolo
column12: are typical adolescents
column13: all caught up in rebellion
column14: identity crises and complicated affairs of the heart.  Although the film attempts to provide some insight into the complexities of modern family life
column15: the characters come across as so whiny and self-indulgent that any sympathy they might have engendered on the part of the audience quickly turns to indifference and even irritation.  The actors do their best (particularly Laura Morante as Giulia)
column16: but the characters they are called on to play never engage us much beyond the surface level.  This lack of depth is further compounded by the whirlwind nature of the storytelling
column17: which rarely allows the actors the time they need to settle down and work out the subtle nuances of their roles.  In all fairness
column18: I must admit that
column19: in the second hour
column20: the film improves considerably
column21: trafficking in some genuinely raw emotions that exemplify the devastating effects that a disintegrating marriage can have on all members of a family.  Moreover
column22: the film ends on a courageously inconclusive note
column23: which goes a long way towards mitigating some of the theatricality and artificiality that permeate the rest of the movie.  Taken as a whole
column24: "Remember Me
column25: My Love" turns out to be much less than the sum of its parts
column26: but the performances and a few good scenes do make it palatable.

column2: I was really looking forward to Huntington's new book as a scholarly, objective consideration of  challenges to America's National Identity."   I ended up deeply disappointed.  My first clue was Huntington's handling (almost dismissal) of the issue of "separation of church and state."  Can one knowledgeable about that issue discuss it historically in an honest
column3: objective way  WITHOUT mentioning Thomas Jefferson.  I hardly think so.  Being a fairly long-term member of Americans United for Separation of Church and State (full disclosure)
column4: I know something about that issue; and Huntington's treatment of it left me suspicious of how much I could trust his other portrayals and analyses to be reasonably objective.  	 I found myself questioning other depictions--for example
column5: a "World Values Survey" of how much "national pride" is associated with "high importance of God" included no Muslim countries at all--in this work much pitting Christianity and Islam against each other.  	Huntington seems not to have been searching for any answer to "Who Are We? -- he'd already made up his mind:  America is " . . defined in large part by its Anglo-Protestant culture and its religiosity."  And the book seems focused on supporting
column6: protecting and projecting that conclusion with a wealth of (selected?) studies and analyses and dealing poorly with alternatives and the "pros" and "cons" of each.  The book will be very well received by those of the neo-conservative/ fundamentalist Christian/militaristic viewpoint; but I don't believe they will learn much

column1: Most military histories of the American Revolution focus on the "great" battles
column2: and give scant attention to recounting other
column3: lesser engagements. However
column4: those lesser engagements are often the best way of depicting the harsh and divisive nature of the war. In the Carolinas
column5: for example
column6: the war took on many aspects of a civil war within a war
column7: as Loyalist militias
column8: stiffened by British soldiers
column9: took on Rebel militias in a brutal
column10: back-country partisan conflict.   This book attempts to describe that slice of the war by highlighting one engagement within it. That small battle
column11: prosaically named "Huck's Defeat" (after Captain Christian Huck
column12: the Loyalist officer who lost his life in the fight)
column13: was the first Rebel victory in the aftermath of the fall of the city of Charleston
column14: and it is the opinion of the author that the importance small militia engagements like this one are overlooked. Huck's Defeat
column15: and several subsequent victories by partisans and militia units
column16: convinced most locals to side with the Rebel forces and oppose the English. This
column17: in turn
column18: kept South Carolina in the war
column19: and ultimately led to the Rebel victories of King's Mountain and the Cowpens. The rest
column20: as they say
column21: is history: the British were forced to leave the state
column22: marching down a path that led to Lord Cornwallis's surrender at Yorktown.   While making a good point - that these lesser back-country battles were important and are often neglected - Edgar overstates his case. "Huck's Defeat" was a very small battle indeed: 115 Loyalist and British soldiers vs. ca. 250 Rebels
column23: and lasting no more than an hour. The loyalists were massacred
column24: but unless the Revolutionary cause in South Carolina truly hinged on this one engagement (i.e. defeat would have meant the end of resistance in the colony)
column25: then it was simply one particularly bloody skirmish among many

Much of the material tracing the earlier history of Jerusalem is well written and quite interesting. However
column2: when the author approaches the re-emergence of a strong Jewish presence in Jerusalem all of her previous objectivity goes out the window as she argues that the Jews brutalize the Arabs and that things would be so much better if only the Jewish majority were ruled by the Arab minority.  Her portrait of Jerusalem as a divided and armed camp on p. 419
column3: "Repeatedly ...." is simply false. It is true that the area of Jaffa Road and King George is no longer mixed
column4: but the commercial interaction between Arabs and Jews has simply moved to Talpiot. You also see many clearly identifiable Arabs at the three campuses of the Hebrew University and both Hadassah hospitals. The remaining area of commercial activity in Jerusalem is the food industry where in restaurants
column5: hotels and grocery stores you see Arabs running the kitchens in most restaurants and running a large part of the operations of many of the grocery stores. I see this every day living here in Jerusalem.   The idea that Jews buying properties and moving into Arab neighborhoods constitutes an act of war has its parallels in the history of black people in the old south. It is a view of someone who rejects the idea that Jewish people are equal with any other people. How sad that the author has wasted her talents to present such a view

column1: Greetings to one and all.  Just wanted you to know that if you are looking for a pretty good film called "The Desperate Hours
column2: this is NOT the one you want to watch. You want to watch the 1955 version with Humphrey Bogart and Fredric March. This is the 1990 remake" with Mickey Rourke and Anthony Hopkins. The original is a taunt drama in which a man discovers that his home has been invaded and his family taken hostage by a trio of gangster escaped from prison and focuses on his desperate attempts to save their lives. This remake is exercise in terror in which the sadistic violence of the criminals becomes the driving force of the story and the goal is to see how far they will go before they are finally stopped. On paper you would have thought Anthony Hopkins could do a marvelous job in the role of the father
column3: but the script pretty much makes that impossible. Turning the bad guy into a major league psychotic just destroys the psychological chess game that made the original so compelling. Rourke is simply the wrong choice for the role
column4: always coming across as a sick punk rather than a criminal menace
column5: but then few actors are going to be able to play against Hopkins
column6: even when he is in low gear. I cannot believe anybody would watch this film twice; I only watched it because I was interested to see how they updated the original
column7: the ending of which I just watched again on television. Of course the ending would be more violent
column8: but it was the elegance of the ending of the original
column9: as the hero saves his family with an unloaded gun
column10: that made it stand out. This one is just a splatter flick dressed up a bit to fool you. Go check out the original because like Rourke's character
column11: you do not want this in your house anywhere near your family

column1: Alhthough Polsky has some interesting insights on the art market
column2: they are relatively few
column3: and are separated by numerous pointless anecdotes and even more pointless details.  For example
column4: in describing a visit to a colleague staying at an upscale Manhattan hotel
column5: Polsky writes that (in case he wanted to stay there in the future) he decided to ask a few questions of the concierge
column6: "a moderately attractive young lady
column7: who was wearing a very businesslike skirt
column8: jacket
column9: silk blouse
column10: and matching bow." (p. 208).  Why exactly does it matter that the concierge was "moderately attractive"?  So we can gauge how excited Polksy was?  So the reader can decide whether he or she would rather stay at a hotel where the concierges are more than "moderately" attractive?  Notably
column11: Polsky then does not even have any questions for the concierge -- so it appears that the whole event was not designed to give him an opportunity to find out if he'd want to stay there in the future (as he claims)
column12: but simply so he can decide how "attractive" the concierge is.  The book abounds in such pointless detail.  The author comes across as self-impressed to an extraordinary degree
column13: and while his occasional insights on the art world are interesting
column14: the reader must suffer through a remarkable amount of banal detail.  Not recommended

column1: This 1987 thriller focuses on Norman Johnson
column2: a psychologist who specializes in large disasters like plane crashes.  As the novel opens he is being taken to an undisclosed site by the US Navy.  Johnson learns that the crash site is located 1000 feet under the South Pacific and the craft is some sort of a space craft.  He was been included because of work he did sometime before organizing a first contact team for a previous administration
column3: an assignment that Johnson would just as soon forget.  Once the team is taken to the Navy deep sea facility and begins to study the craft Johnson begins to find disturbing circumstances - that the Navy commander has been less than honest with both the team and his superiors and that the craft itself bears a remarkable similiarity to current human technology
column4: labels and directions are even written in English
column5: leading the team to question just how alien this technology really is.  The suspense continues to build as the undersea facility loses their support ships above due to inclement weather and then conditions in the facility itself begins to turn hostile.  This novel is quite predictable
column6: just a few pages into the story it is obvious to anyone who has ever seen a disaster movie that there will be no comforting support ships nearby
column7: that the undersea environment will become threatening
column8: there will be many deaths
column9: there will be sexual tension between the hero and someone else and so on.  While there is some slight redemption in the last few pages this book is a big disappointment
column10: Crichton is capable of so much more.  If you are a fan read it but be forewarned
column11: if you are unfamiliar with his work begin with anything but this.

column1: "In My Country" is certainly a well meaning film.  Filled with dignity
column2: it means to explore the atrocities committed in the age of Apartheid.  Can justice be served?  Can South Africa move on?  How complicit is the average man?  There are certainly important topics and issues to be dealt with--but rarely have I seen them served up so falsely and dispassionately.    Everything in "In My Country" is a construct.  You've got Juliette Binoche as the face of white shame
column3: Samuel L. Jackson as black rage (though he's an American)
column4: Brendan Gleeson as the villain
column5: Binoche's assistant as the tolerant and understanding African
column6: and her boss as the face of white indifference.  Of course
column7: this story is told from the vantage point of the white lady and the American--as these stories rarely examine issues from the African viewpoint.  Even the testimony of atrocities--which should be a dramatic highpoint--are so staged
column8: so false with the requisite swoons from the audience at "shocking" revelations.  And Binoche is ever present to provide the tears--but as the emotion isn't genuinely developed
column9: I continued to sit there feeling rather empty at the whole exercise.  The Africans are never portrayed as significant indivduals
column10: but as understanding and forgiving souls.  I'd have appreciated a bit of emotional complexity at any point!  If the pairing of Juliette Binoche and Samuel L. Jackson seems an odd match
column11: trust me--it is.  As characters with opposing views
column12: they are put together rather conveniently.  No actual friendship is ever developed
column13: we're just supposed to take it at face value that these two would hang out together.  Well
column14: I didn't believe it for a second.  It was necessary for the plot
column15: so it happened--why bother with actual character development?  There's a more important message to be delivered by having them debate.  Of course
column16: to make matters worse--a romantic entanglement evolves.  There's not much drama there
column17: either
column18: as Binoche seemingly has an indifference to her husband and children.  If she's conflicted about anything
column19: it certainly never shows.  And as if matters aren't bad enough
column20: there's a heavy-handed (and obvious) ending that is supposed to be a revelatory twist.  But I can only say it once more
column21: without bothering to make the characters real--who cares?    A message can only take you so far.  I'd have rather have watched a relevant speech
column22: because no one here was concerned with drama.

column1: Do dogs understand language?  Do they have their own syntax and grammar?  Stanley Coren thinks so.  Or maybe
column2: as with many of his other books
column3: he's only pretending to believe what he says in order to pique people's interest and sell more copies...  The words we use in dog training are actually irrelevant.  Since I train dogs in Manhattan
column4: I often find myself on an elevator with one or more dogs.  When the door closes I'll say
column5: "What do we do on an elevator?" and they'll all sit.  This often charms and surprises the other elevator occupants who may say something like
column6: "Look!  They understand every word you say!"    Not really.  I trained the dogs to do this by first saying "What do we do on an elevator?-we sit."  Once that pattern was established
column7: the dogs were able to make the leap from "What do we do on an elevator?" to "Sit" quite easily.  In fact
column8: I could have as easily trained them to do this by using nonsense words
column9: gobbledygook
column10: ridiculous sounds that have no meaning at all.  So it isn't my words or syntax the dogs are responding to
column11: it's my intent
column12: my body language
column13: my tone of voice (all carrying emotional information)
column14: and a previously established pattern of behavior.    Stanley Coren should know this better than anyone since one of his dogs is deaf
column15: yet still obeys him.  Why?  Because of his body language and a previously established pattern of behavior
column16: not because the dog "understands" his words.  Coren would say that the dog understands his hand signals the same way the hearing-impaired understand sign language.  But looked at objectively it's far more likely that the dog's response to hand signals is still just part of a previously established pattern of behavior
column17: not a linguistic or cognitive process.   Coren would still disagree.  He claims that certain vocalizations made by dogs can be grouped together
column18: which he takes to mean that there's a kind of syntax or grammar at work.  I'm sorry
column19: Stan
column20: but real language doesn't operate on such a simplistic level.  And while it may seem brave and controversial of Coren (who has a degree in psychology
column21: not linguisics or animal behavior) to disagree with Noam Chomsky about the nature of language
column22: at this stage in the development of linguistic science that's a bit like a high school sophmore disagreeing with Sir Isaac Newton about gravity.    Look
column23: it's fairly obvious to anyone who really understands dogs that the reason certain yips
column24: barks
column25: growls
column26: etc. are sometimes used together and others aren't (which isn't always true
column27: by the way -- it depends on the dog)
column28: is that each vocalization comes from an emotional
column29: not a cognitive state.  In other words
column30: certain emotions -- like fear and aggression -- may be felt by the animal simultaneously
column31: while others -- calmness and fear -- can't be.  It's not grammar or syntax
column32: it's emotion
column33: pure and simple.    Even if Coren hadn't thought this through from an emotional point of view
column34: if he'd spent any time at all studying comparative neuroanatomy he'd know that a dog's brain has no Broca's area
column35: which makes linguistic ability totally impossible.  But as with other books he's written (his LEFT-HANDER SYNDROME was notorious for being based on false data)
column36: Coren doesn't seem to care much about the truth.    Still
column37: I have to admit that it's hard not to buy into this myth because as human beings we're constantly explaining our feelings and experiences to ourselves through our thoughts and inner monologues
column38: or to others through conversations
column39: letters
column40: etc.  As a result we're almost forced
column41: by the way our brains work
column42: to supply a similar linguistic medium for a dog's feelings and behaviors when no such medium or ability exists.    I trained my dog to respond in a certain way whenever I ask him a certain question.  And I have to admit
column43: I like the way it feels when I say to him
column44: "Do you love me?" and he wags his tail
column45: comes over
column46: puts his paws on my chest
column47: and licks my nose.  Does he understand the meaning of that sentence when I say it to him?  Of course not.  But I know he understands the emotion.  It's a shame that Coren doesn't get this fundamental difference between real linguistic understanding and pure emotion
column48: particularly when the misinformation he disseminates in this book can be detrimental to the relationship between you and your dog
column49: a relationship that SHOULD be based on real and
column50: quite often
column51: wonderful emotions
column52: not on any imaginary ability to use and understand language.    If I could I'd give this book no stars at all

column1: Stories of a Westerner exploring Middle Eastern Christianity normally leads to such disasters as When Angels Fall
column2: so I came to Dalrymple's book a bit skeptical. As I expected
column3: Dalrymple never escapes his western notions about religion. Some were simply annoying
column4: like constantly calling a censer a thurible. Others
column5: such as praising religious relativism and bashing religious particularism
column6: were distressing. While Dalymple is obviously well read and highly intelligent
column7: I got the feeling throughout the book that he had simply read up on the religious and social histories of the groups he met
column8: and never thought to bother with examining their theological literature. It comes as no surprise then when he writes how aghast he was with the fundamentalism of Mount Athos and Saint Saba
column9: or that he is highly skeptical of relic veneration. What it boils down to
column10: eventually
column11: is that his book is little more than a superficial travelogue
column12: and nothing near the thing he was trying to imitate
column13: The Spiritual Meadow.  	Having been in some of the places and met some of the kinds of people mentioned in the book
column14: Dalrymple has an uncanny way to make the idiosyncrasies of the people and places of the Middle East shine through. Most amusing was his account of the brand-new Syrian church in Turkey
column15: all dressed up in the finest neon and flashing lights. As a fellow westerner of Dalrymple
column16: I sympathize fully with his reaction of horror. His method of dealing with the political climate was also amusing
column17: demonstrating the patience and long-suffering needed to wrangle with Middle Eastern politics.  	Having lived in Jerusalem for some time
column18: I found his experiences in Palestine to be most interesting. Having personally seen the rows of cactus plants surrounding bombed out rubble
column19: deserted on the sides of roads or within mostly useless National Parks
column20: the devastation is staggering. The displaced Maronite village Dalrymple visits is no small secret
column21: my professor told my class their story when we passed their current village in the bus
column22: yet their situation is far from resolved. The overarching sentiment of the Palestinian Christians
column23: that they fail to understand the western "Christian" support for a state which mistreats their Christian brothers and sisters
column24: I also felt acutely. The dichotomy between the local Christians who are trying to scrape together their traditional existence and western Christians who seem to believe that the only real people living in Israel are Jews and the Arabs and their history should cease to exist
column25: is so great that they seem to exist on different planets.   	While the current Israeli government seems to be
column26: as Dalrymple says
column27: trying to co-exist with its Christian population peacefully
column28: not everything is roses. Having met Canon Naim Ateek myself
column29: I hardly consider him to be an accurate source of information
column30: just propaganda. The Israeli army now undergoes sensitivity training to Christianity
column31: though this is done at a pro-Israeli Catholic monastery. The main problem is that western money
column32: whether from Jewish or Evangelical Christian sources
column33: is concerned with preserving "biblical" sites
column34: which fits into the Israeli national history nicely
column35: but leaves Byzantine history out in the cold. My school took field trips to two major monastic centers in the Judean desert which have long been in ruins
column36: including the monastery of St Euthemius. Both are under the National Park Authority
column37: though both were nearly impossible to find and lacked proper facilities. The reason for this was simple
column38: our group was likely the only visitors they got all week
column39: if not all month. Another major Byzantine site which had over five ancient basilica churches was slated to come under the National Park Authority soon
column40: though it was uncertain if this was being done in interest of the site or because the site had a great view of the sunset over the Lake of Galilee. Jewish and western tourists being uninterested in Byzantine things
column41: Byzantine sites lack economic potential. Turning a Maronite village into an ancient Jewish revolutionary camp automatically turns it into a money making place. So the mistreatment of Palestinian Christians
column42: currently
column43: is more of an economic enterprise rather than racial discrimination.   	One of the most striking omissions in Dalrymple's book is his failure to visit the Christian Old Quarter of Cairo. His reliance on the Spiritual Meadow shows its bias very clearly here. Since John Moschos considered it to be a heretical holdout of the uneducated Copts
column44: Dalrymple apparently saw little need to put it on his itinerary
column45: hence he leaves out a great chunk of Coptic history. Furthermore
column46: his references to "screaming Coptic monks" sacking Alexandria and his comments about how Coptic sounds inherently "incantational" may be his personal opinion
column47: but it displays his western bias quite clearly. For Dalrymple
column48: the Copts are among the strangest of the strange
column49: and he clearly has done little to understand them or their religious outlook.  	Dalrymple
column50: it becomes obvious
column51: is most at home among the Maronites. He spends an inordinate amount of time talking about them considering that John Moschos never mentions them. For Dalrymple's point of view
column52: because the Maronites are western he understands them better
column53: therefore he regards them more highly. Maronite practices such as speaking English and French fluently
column54: being educated in the west
column55: and their clergy wearing street clothes
column56: are obviously reassuring to Dalrymple
column57: and so he judges them quite favorably. Byzantines are
column60: the Byzantine-like Armenians and Syrians are odd in a cute way
column61: but the Copts are beyond the pale of his cognition. At St. Anthony's he can do little more than speculate for many pages how an artistic motif there also shows up in Scotland
column62: and praise the ancient western-focused Coptic missionaries. Redeemable
column64: that they were smart enough to go to Scotland
column65: unlike their modern compatriots who think the desert is the only place to learn anything.   Also
column66: the attitude of Dalrymple towards relics and saints is little more than cynical. He goes to ridiculous lengths trying to explain away a miracle recounted in the Spiritual Meadow
column70: to appease his offended rational mind. He is overtly suspicious of legends and saints
column71: preferring to question them rather than learn what they have to say about the people who believe in them. This gives the impression that Dalrymple does not want his worldview to be challenged
column72: even if it is to recognize a parallel one. In Dalrymple's worldview the dead do not appear in dreams
column73: people who think they do are deluded. While this is a very common western perception
column74: I would have expected someone as widely traveled and read as Dalrymple to have overcome it enough to not dwell on it in his book. Perhaps he has
column75: but he believes that these things made fascinating reading for westerners
column76: so he puts in these oddities for entertainment purposes. However
column77: in the end it does little but reconfirm the superiority of the western worldview to the readers and make the Middle Eastern Christians worldview look childish and stupid.   Dalrymple's praise of the glory days of Alexandria was interesting
column78: but mostly had very little to do with the Spiritual Meadow or Middle Eastern Christians. Instead
column79: it was a time for Dalrymple to bemoan the loss of a western city to "Arabism". John Moschos really would have cared less if the theatre left Alexandria
column81: but for Dalrymple this is blasphemy. Dalrymple incessantly praises the previous multi-culturalism of Alexandria
column82: going to far to suggest that Alexandria is the place where Christian theology came into existence because it was there that Christianity syncretized with the world's religions
column83: only to be strayed by murderous "howling" Coptic monks. Here Dalrymple's lack of understanding about religious history and development becomes more than painfully obvious.  	While Dalrymple has the vague notion that the current situation of Christians in the Middle East is on the brink of disaster
column84: his ideals about these Christians is mostly romantic. Dalrymple exudes the feeling that the Middle Eastern Christians should just be like the Maronites
column88: and give up their fundamentalist notions
column89: and everything will be better. Dalrymple seems not to realize that with the current anti-western propaganda in Middle Eastern Islam
column90: the further the Christians keep away from the West and Israel
column91: the better it is for them. This is not to say that the current Western practice of ignoring Middle Eastern Christians should continue
column92: simply that the current Maronite practice of adopting everything Western does little than confirm in Islamic minds that Christianity is a western plot.   	Overall
column93: Dalrymple is a very good writer in that he does a wonderful job painting the landscape and feeling of a place and culture. However
column94: his cultural and religious bias gets in the way of him actually understanding what is going on. I came away from the book with the feeling of sadness
column95: both for what Christians in the Middle East are presently going through and for insurmountable gap that exists between the worldview of western Christians and that of their religious birthplace.

column1: On the surface
column2: John Waters has it all -- a loving wife
column3: a beautiful child
column4: a successful business -- but appearances are deceiving. His marriage is in trouble
column5: his business is under investigation by a federal agency
column6: and his business partner has made questionable financial decisions which jeopardize everyone's future. Into this mix wanders Eve Sumner
column7: a stunningly attractive woman who makes it abundantly obvious she's chosen Waters as her next conquest. However
column8: appearances are again deceiving
column9: because Eve Sumner claims she is actually Mallory Chandler
column10: Waters' first great love.  Funny thing
column11: though: Mallory Chandler died ten years previously.  So who is this woman? And how does she know things only Mallory should know?  In an effort to discover the truth
column12: Waters finds himself involved in an affair that quickly turns dangerous
column13: as Eve/Mallory displays the same obsessive behavior that destroyed Waters' love for Mallory twenty years before.  This novel requires a major suspension of disbelief for its critical plot device: transmigration of a soul. Once the reader accepts that
column14: however
column15: the story moves along quickly and works well within its preposterous premise. Waters flails and fumbles and does his best to fix the mess he's made by getting involved with Eve/Mallory
column16: even as she seems to be setting him up for a murder charge. His desperation and fear are palpable
column17: and certainly mitigate his at times wrong-headed choices. I truly enjoyed this story
column18: that is
column19: until I read the final pages.  The final plot twist
column20: which I won't reveal here
column21: is so farfetched
column22: even within the confines of a plot that stretches suspension of disbelief to its outermost limit
column23: as to spoil all the good trashiness that preceded it. I read the last few pages and threw the book across the room. I felt cheated. I think Mr. Iles wrote himself into a corner and couldn't think of any other way to give the reader a happy ending. Gah.  Never have I been so disappointed with a novel's resolution.  Oh
column24: and the frequent references to a novel written by a character within this novel which happens to have the same title as a novel written by Iles bugged me too.  Gah.  Oh. Go ahead and read the story. Just rewrite the ending in your own head. I did

column4: likely

column16: as of January 2007

column5: which turned up several dozen bad blocks
column6: some of them in the regions generally used for metadata on the FAT filesystem most cameras use.  That's potentially a serious issue
column7: because while all modern filesystems can be given lists of bad blocks to avoid
column8: rendering partially faulty media usable
column9: digital cameras and other embedded devices often use partial implementations of filesystem standards and may not honor bad block lists

otherwise I would have given this heart-tugging nostalgia-waxing book 5 stars. Sigh, is nothing sacred anymore? Apparently not 
 Gardner's book is full of banal and often incorrect observations. It's hard to believe he has received over 20 honorary degrees from universities around the world if his ideas are this unoriginal. He chooses the staggeringly bad examples of Margaret Thatcher, George Bush and BP CEO John Browne as people who have successfully changed minds. He doesn't mention that Thatcher and Bush antagonized large sections of their countries' populations, completely failing to change their minds, in fact hardening their positions of opposition; in large part due to these leaders' own refusal to ever change their minds or consider alternative policies. Gardner lavishes praise on Bush for switching from isolationism to an interventionist foreign policy after 9/11, without any mention of the PNAC team that had already planned to invade Iraq even before 9/11.   As for John Browne, his claim to have repositioned BP as an environmentally and socially concerned company has been discredited in the past year with the explosion at a Texas refinery and the oil spill on the North Slope that led to the admission that BP hadn't done any of the anti-corrosion work it was supposed to do on its pipelines.   Another poor example is Lawrence Summers of Harvard. For some reason Gardner doesn't mention the biggest controversy Summers was involved with, when he said that women could never be as good at science as men. Gardner's use of case studies from academia is another bad choice because most readers won't have heard of these professors and won't care much about their internal disputes. It's a shame Gardner didn't tackle any real-life problems, such as how to change the minds of Creationists.   Gardner insists on using she" and "her" instead of "he" and "his" as the neutral pronoun for political correctness
column3: and another irritating habit he has is to invent jargon that will obviously never catch on
column4: such as "wetware" and "dryware" for the internal workings of the brain and "GoodWork" for being ethical at work
column5: yet another painfully banal concept.   In one section Gardner describes how a psychologist uses a patient's dream to understand how the patient sees himself (or should I say herself even if he was male?) in relation to others
column6: which sounds to me like total cod psychology
column7: but that's just my own reaction to dream interpretations.   Regarding computers
column8: Gardner believes that people are starting to prefer interaction with computers over interaction with other people. This again is utterly mistaken and it's clear that Gardner has next to no experience with the internet. Thanks to the internet there has been an explosion in human interaction and far more people talk with other people than with computers. Gardner says people can get emotional solace from interaction with computers that are programmed to communicate and cites a book written in 1995
column9: but gives no further justification of this claim.   Anyone writing about changing minds ought to have a full understanding of how people use the internet and communicate on all kinds of levels that weren't possible before this technology existed
column10: for example role-playing or participating in a political discussion forum
column11: as well as absorbing surreptitious marketing on the internet.   Gardner's specific advice on how to change minds consists of using a variety of words that all begin with "re" for convenience
column12: eg resonance and resistance. I had hoped to learn how to communicate my ideas better from this book
column13: but all I learnt was that it was a bad book.
