column1: I don't know whether Seinfeld creator Larry David had A Nos Amours in mind for the mock Eurotrash film that appears in repeated episodes
column2: Rochelle
column3: Rochelle. There are so many French films that could be described as "a young girl's strange erotic journey from Milan to Minsk" - the sexual activities/awakenings of pretty young teenagers is somewhat of a national obsession. It's hard to pick just one.  Maurice Pialat is widely known as "the French Cassavetes" (or
column4: if you are British
column5: "the French Ken Loach") which is the shorthand way of saying he's French
column6: made films on the fringe of the European studio system
column7: imbued his pictures with unsentimental realism
column8: and is well-liked by film snobs who see Pialat's lack of relative mainstream success on these shores as proof of their sophisticated taste. His feature length debut
column9: L'Enfance Nue
column10: was tendered the Francois Truffaut mark of approval (it was produced by the master) as well as a Prix Jean Figo. That award is given each year to a promising French director
column11: generally a young one though Pialat was a forty-four when he got his. He cemented his reputation as un auteur with 1987's Sous le soleil de Satan
column12: which not only won him the Palme d'Or but iconoclast status for life when he flipped off some booing audience members while accepting it. Sounds like a guy I could like.  If only A Nos Amours were a better film.  The picture stars sixteen-year-old Sandrine Bonnaire as the frequently-nude (not as titillating as it sounds) Suzanne
column13: a confused French teenager wandering from one hollow sexual encounter to the next. She says she's only happy when she's in the arms of one of her paramours and we don't blame her: Suzanne's home-life is at best unusual
column14: at worst fairly grotesque. Dad (played by Pialat himself) flies the coop early on
column15: leaving his son
column16: pudgy tyrant Robert (Dominique Besnehard) in charge of both daughter and half-crazy Mom (Evelyne Ker). Emotional and physical abuse relents only for short passages of awkward conversation
column17: often hinging on some sort of inappropriately sexual subject that tinges everything in something akin to unconsummated incest. Mom calls daughter a slut who trades sex advice with Dad while fielding interminable compliments about her body from her brother who himself has become a surrogate husband to Mom. Everyone in this family (Suzanne included) seeks to make life miserable for everyone else
column18: and in their own creepy ways they succeed.  Plenty of women seek the affections of too many men (or too many of the wrong men) to compensate for an absent father - such are the incontrovertible facts that clich is made of. It's the sort of unsophisticated platitude-masquerading-as-wisdom we've come to expect from daytime talk shows
column19: peddled to prostitutes and cheating spouses. In his own quasi-verit manner
column20: I imagine Pialat was seeking to subvert the clich
column21: deconstruct it
column22: transcend it - rarely does it actually come off. The meandering quarrels
column23: beatings
column24: and post-coital chit-chats all have the feel of work-shopping actors being put through an exercise rather than real life
column25: even the life of a sexually-obsessed French person. Pialat never truly gets under the surface of these characters
column26: frquently mistaking the bizarre and cruel for honest characterization (it's no surprise Catherine Breillat is such a fan of a the picture). One hundred minutes pass
column27: and yet we still feel as though we do not know these characters - they remain only our acquaintances
column28: obnoxious ones at that
column29: and if it's all the same we rather wish we hadn't been introduced.  Interesting footnote: One of Suzanne's first sexual conquests is an American tourist - we meet him as his has an argument with some French sailors
column30: whom he calls warmongers. This is probably the only time in cinema you will see an American character call a French one a warmonger

column1: I was mislead into wasting money on Jim Fay's audio book on toddlers and I think Amazon and other  booksellers have a responsibility to be honest with consumers about this series;   The author as a promoted as a "doctor" and yet the series is  about heavy handed fundamentalist Christian parenting.  I used to live in Denver
column2: and because the authors made several references to Colorado I began to wonder  if this were something put out by the "Focus on the Family" extremist cult based in Colorado Springs;  I was right. The titles and descriptions are deliberately misleading
column3: but if you click on the copyright link you'll see that this is where it came from.  When did these extreme Christian fundamentalist pass an amendment to the "Shall not lie" commandment? When did it become a "Christian Value" to disguise
column4: mislead and lie about an agenda in order to sell something that they know the buyer would have avoided had we been given honest information beforehand?  For me
column5: this validates the fear that a lot of people in Colorado had expressed about this group. It also shows how  much the extreme Christian right has in common with the Muslim extremist in Afghanistan:  Both groups are willing to disregard the core dictates of the  religion they claim to follow if it serves their efforts to make money or to impose their  beliefs on the rest of the word.  I purchased the "Toddler Love and Logic" audio book from this series
column6: and after the first 10 minutes of listening  to the these two men laughing at (and sarcastically imitating  the voices of) mother's they've overheard making " mistakes" in conversations with their children
column7: I realized the real mistake had been in wasting my money.  Why would they use "Logic" in the title of a book that tells parents that they shouldn't take the time to explain the reasoning behind the 'commands' they make to their children? And what is logical about using a child's bedroom as a punishment during the day and expecting them to  view it as a comfortable safe place at bedtime?

column1: Although this book may be so brilliantly written by John Reed

column7: it is always better to read a book which describes that event perhaps in a very broad outline form on the first page of the book.  The rest of the book should be written according to that outline. A glossary of main events would also be helpful.  On the other hand I do realize that most historical events are way too complicated to be approached in this manner.  Anyway
column8: if you would like to expand your knowledge about the Russian Revolution
column9: I highly recommend this book.  However
column10: if like me you are looking to merely acquire a basic knowledge about this historical event you will get lost in its too many facts

This book provides a very simplistic view of the sociological ramifications of the Rolling Stones.   One or two of the other online reviewers correctly state that this book provides a very limited view of the Stones
column2: in that Watts and Wood seem to be mostly "yes men
column3: and no one who would contest Mick and Keith are given a voice.  Where are Bill Wyman, Mick Taylor, Marianne Faithfull, Anita Pallenberg et al.?   Way too much space is devoted to the period after 1972.  I couldn't care less about their disco period, the 80s, etc.  Half of the book involves Ron Wood who is, at best, a mediocre guitar player.  One chapter is entitled The New Kid" (referring to Wood).  Barf.  The majority of the book should have focused on '62-'72.  I suppose the Stones feel obligated to talk about such garbage as "Dirty Work"
column4: but it's only to make those later pieces seem more important than they were.  Ron Wood wrote many of the songs on "Dirty Work".  What does that tell you about his ability?   The multitude of photographs point to the fact the rock and roll is mostly a visual phenomenon these days (probably caused by the Stones!).  Substance is not as important as attitude
column5: looks
column6: and for lack of a better word "coolness".  It's sad to see less intellectual content and more filler from the people who gave us "Gimme Shelter"
column7: "Satisfaction"
column8: "Dead Flowers"
column9: etc. After just seeing the documentary "Gimme Shelter
column10: it becomes painfully obvious that the Stones were probably washed up as early as 1970.  Ironically, it may have been Mick Taylor (who is trashed by everyone interviewed) who kept them going musically for the next few years.  I'm not sure if it's true but I read that many of the tracks for Exile on Main Street" were written during the sessions for "Let It Bleed".  Interesting.   Is it possible that Keith's drug problems completely ruined the band and that they couldn't come up with new
column11: good material after he became addicted to heroin in `69?  None of this is explored.  In fact
column12: no topic is approached with the level headedness you would hope for from men in their 60s.   Consideration is given to whether Wood or Jagger wrote "It's Only Rock and Roll."  It's like arguing over who deserves credit for picking Eagleton as McGovern's running mate.        Even with his loyalty to the bosses
column13: Watts provides reasonably interesting material.  Mick Jagger's sections are a total waste
column14: just pathetic in terms of providing insight.  I'm convinced after reading this book and seeing "Gimme Shelter" that Mick Jagger has the mind of a child.  Keith basically goofs around.  This shouldn't come as a shock if you have seen any footage from the `60s where Richards' PR consisted of him sticking his tongue out at a camera.   "Stone Alone" by Wyman is a quantum leap above this book
column15: although in fairness to "According to the Rolling Stones"

column1: I expected this book to be about PARENTING an only child per its title and was disappointed. Susan Newman did touch on some important issues such as teaching sharing and respectfulness and avoiding loneliness
column2: although there wasn't a lot of meat to the chapters on these subjects. She also discussed being careful not to have excessive expectations of an only child
column3: which I found interesting. However
column4: a great deal of this book was devoted to justifying the decision to have an only child. If you're struggling with your family planning choices and would like someone to tell you repeatedly you're doing the right thing
column5: you may enjoy this book. At this point
column6: I don't need justification
column7: I need information on addressing relevant issues so that I can be the best possible parent to my child. I also do not need reasons why my decision to have an only child is "superior" to the paths other families choose and was a little disturbed by the author's tone. Bottom line: this book effectively identifies some concerns of parents of only children
column8: but I will be looking elsewhere for more substantial parenting support

column1: This brief novel offers a rather pointless speculative fiction take on Conrad's Heart of Darkness. A ridiculous and under-explained premise is used to prop up some equally under-explained ruminations from Ballard on the human condition and spirituality. Here the action takes place in an African jungle that is becoming crystallized
column2: as all objects slowly become encrusted with luminous jewels. Ballard doesn't explain how this process works except for some weak references to the "crystallized" time and space aspects of relativity. This implausible premise leads to curious changes in the people who also find themselves crystallized
column3: with some sort of inner peace and spiritual fulfillment being found in the process
column4: though Ballard leaves this aspect of the story anemic as well
column5: other than some flimsy philosophical ramblings. Meanwhile
column6: the action of the story mostly involves a pointless chase sequence connected to a blood feud between two shallow supporting characters
column7: which is never resolved within the story. Add to all of this the book's outdated colonialist conceptions of the third world and its inhabitants
column8: and the weak premise and theme of this novel retreat further into the crystal haze. [~doomsdayer520~

column1: David Fromkin's "Peace to End All Peace" is simultaneously a comprehensive and very flawed work. Many of the reasons for it being one can be found in the other.  Fromkin attempts to examine how the modern Middle East (extending as far as Afghanistan and some sections of Central Asia) was created during and after the First World War. Obviously
column2: in order to do this
column3: the fall of the Ottoman Empire in that war must be considered. This is where Fromkin's unusual methodology comes into play. Focusing on the European political machinations to resolve the "Eastern Question" in their favour
column4: the sorry tale becomes one more of Churchill and TE Lawrence than of the Arabs and Turks who were also involved in the process. Admittedly
column5: it was the Europeans who wielded the whip hand in deciding just where the borders were to be drawn
column6: but reducing key figures such as the CUP Triumvirate in the dying Ottoman Empire (and Kemal Ataturk in Turkey immediately thereafter) to the status of supporting players ultimately skews the focus of the book too much.  Never let it be said that this is a simple story to retell. A complex web of national and personal political interests in both Europe and the Middle East combined to make the region what it is today
column7: and any study of all of these will be faced with the need for convoluted explanations. The problem that Fromkin has
column8: however
column9: is that he does not make these very well at all. The story is told in a roughly chronological manner
column10: which means that we jump from place to place and meet a bewildering array of characters. Ultimately
column11: the only real result is confusion on the part of the reader
column12: who is constantly flipping backwards to see who the latest figure to make an appearance actually is.  Additionally
column13: Fromkin frequently confuses his readers with references to geographical features which are not well-shown on the maps provided. Indeed
column14: one map (showing Enver Pasha's advance on Baku and his campaigns in Central Asia) is laughable in the extreme. The legend explains that the direction of the arrows is the direction of the various advances - which would be significantly more useful were the arrows in fact arrows
column15: and not equilateral triagles.  Where Fromkin does well
column16: however
column17: is in his use of purely European sources. It is perhaps unusual to say this of a book intending to tell the story of the modern Middle East
column18: but I have considerable doubts about the depth of his research into the Middle Eastern aspects of the events in question. In terms of Europe
column19: however
column20: his research seems to cover the major bases of exactly what the key figures believed and did.  Ultimately
column21: "A Peace to End All Peace" is a difficult and not particularly rewarding work. A diplomatic history of Europe during the Great War can be written much better than this
column22: and a history of the development of the Middle East following that conflict already has been (the chapters in Margaret Attwood's "The Peacemakers" or William Cleveland's "Modern Middle East" both easily outshine this)

column2: which under some circumstances is associated with fibrotic heart lesions coupled with a very high sulphur content and goes rancid easily (Nourishing Traditions
column3: 2001).  Not to mention Mr. Piscatella condemns tropical oils which are high in lauric acid which are not only stable at high temperatures but has high antifungal and antimicrobial properties.  Guess where lauric acid also can be found?  Mother's milk and we certainly don't condemn that.........yet!  On cholesterol
column4: he's just wrong.  Or should I say the FDA is wrong.  On page 21 Mr. Piscatella emphasizes the importance of LDL and HDL ratios.  This is a typical FDA propaganda tool.  In the book

column7: PhD

So I thought that investing in the most recent edition of this book would behoove me
column2: but upon looking up one of the "author's picks
column3:
for lodging, I discover that he and Lonely Planet have not updated the book for the hotel's *price.*  This is really important to me, as I work in non-profit and can't afford expensive digs when travelling.    The author and Lonely Planet state that Renakse Hotel in Phnom Penh costs $25-50/night.  I understand that hotel prices change over time, but prices I bought this book fresh off the press last month.  Prices at Renakse are now a whopping $76-100/night and they have been since the end of 2004.  The author's writing style is great, but you may want to pick up an older version of the book (4th edition seems just the same as this one when I read it before getting this one) and save the extra bucks.  
 I was really excited when I saw this DVD and really DEFLATED when I actually attempted to complete it!  The instructor gives relatively little if any INSTRUCTION on how to successfully complete moves; and she switches from combo to combo, move to move and it is virtually impossible to keep up.  I have also never sweated so much in my life, mostly from a rise in my blood pressure from anger and frustration!  I am in relatively good shape; I walk up to 3 miles a day and wanted this to break the routine.  In only broke my spirits!  Unless you are an accomplished club hopper or a trained hoofer, STAY AWAY!  One of the worst workouts I have ever seen

This is one American who has no intention of putting any money in the pocket of someone who holds me and my fellow countrymen in such open and unbridled contempt. column1: One of the most important elements in a horror film is that the audience has to either
column2: identify or care about the potential victim. In this case
column3: I felt neither.  It's hard to be sympathetic towards people who are genuinely stupid. I'll explain. The girl in this film is being hunted by a deranged killer in a commercial pick-up truck. He steals her boyfriend away to take him to his gruesome and torturous demise. Once she realizes he is missing
column4: she sticks around (all alone) in a deserted rest stop to get drunk on a bottle of whiskey that she discovers in a police officers desk. She calls for help and when a police officer arrives it turns out to be Joey Lawrence! Wough!! The killer runs over Joey and his death scene is acually quite comical. I can only hope the director was playing it for laughs because it is like something out of Monty Python. Joey is laying on a floor and he begs the girl to shoot him in the head to relieve him of his agonizing misery. She reluctantly agrees and sticks the pistol in his wide open flapper. She pulls the trigger and the next shot is Joey Lawrence laying on the ground with half his brains splattered on the floor telling her "You missed!
column5: do it again" at that point I was waiting for John Cleese and Eric Idle to walk out and go into "The Lumberjack Song." This movie would be best viewed at Thanksgiving because it is one Freakin Big Turkey!!!!!

column5: see bug submission below for more information.  So

I mean place and use the device like it was my trusty AAA map. - Support does not read bug reports (I want that job with zero accountability please!)  Does it work? column1: This book was obviously slapped together as quickly as possibly to take advantage of the (at that time) rapidly emerging Microchip PIC market.  A significant amount of it is completely irrelevant or even misleading material which apparently was copied from the author's previous books about completely different processors.  Another large part is just verbatim copies of free Microchip literature.    Of the material that appears to be original
column2: there is in my opinion too much opinion and anecdote.  This is debatable
column3: as some readers will prefer a "chatty" style.  Worse
column4: however
column5: there are many
column6: many errors
column7: something on the order of one per page. (!)  Some are editing problems such as typographical and grammar errors
column8: but a distressingly large number show a real lack of understanding of his subject material.  I feel the author's "I'm so smart" attitude comes through as well
column9: and is particularly annoying when combined with the above.  The PCB and code included for building a programmer don't work -- more evidence of rushing to publish.  In his defense
column10: he has posted "updates" on his web site which address this problem
column11: but as I understand it they require a lot of changes and don't completely solve the problems of the original design
column12: which he has abandoned in favor of another.  This is a sufficiently unprofessional effort that would I regard with great suspicion any other of the author's many similar works.  It was more than a waste of my money -- it was a waste of time and sanity.  I'd pay to never have seen it.

 If your looking for an autobiography of someones life then this is the book for you.  But if your buying the book to learn the darvas system of the stock market then this is not the book for you.  I gave this book a 1 star rating because the book jacket said that the book contained information about nicolas darvas' system for profiting in the market.  But nowhere in this book does he give you any information about it or how to use it. It sounds like all he did was buy a stock that was in a strong uptrend and then bought it when it passed the resistance level.  Nicholas also gained most of his money when he bought a cheap stock on a wim for maybe 5 or 10 dollars and it shot up in price overnight and was restricted for anymore trading.  He ended up selling for 171 dollars a share and sold for a profit of 250,000.  His idea of buying resistance is nothing new and it sounds like he was lucky more than anything else.

column1: Gary Sicks' bizarro theory that George Bush flew to Paris in an SR-71 to meet with the Iranians to convince them to keep the hostages until after the election in 1990 is just plain crazy. As such

column5: and even in its very title) to anyone looking for a reliable examination and presentation of Tolkien's own Sindarin

column10: this book can be useful for the student as an introduction to a more accurate and detailed study of Tolkien's own Sindarin

column1: Julian Simon won a famous ten-year-long bet with Paul Erlich regarding the prices of certain resources in the 1980's
column2: which Simon predicted would decline in real terms. If Simon hadn't died a few years ago and he had made a similar set of bets with someone starting in 1995 for resources like Atlantic cod
column3: copper
column4: nickel
column5: natural gas in North America and petroleum
column6: by 2005 he would have lost
column7: and spectacularly so. Apparently Simon's model for "unlimited" resources has begun to break down. The increasingly strained world oil supply shows that throwing more ingenuity and money at a resource problem can't always solve it. For example
column8: despite having access to petroleum and natural gas from the North Sea
column9: with the double-digit decline in North Sea output the British government has plans for _rationing_ fossil fuels this winter (2005-06) in the event of prolonged frigid weather.   And why do people keep referring to the Simon/Ehrlich bet any way? It doesn't follow from that contest that things haven't gone awry now.   As for the reviewer who blames government regulations and environmentalists for our current resource constraints
column10: consider the following:  1. The world consumes a billion barrels of oil every 12 days or so at the current rate
column11: up by 20 percent from a decade ago. If environmentalists and government regulators have tried to interfere with the growth of this flow of petroleum
column12: they have clearly failed.  2. Much of our oil comes from parts of the world with few or no environmental restrictions. Even within the U.S.
column13: people along the Gulf Coast live with a level of petroleum-derived pollution and environmental damage that the rest of the country wouldn't tolerate.   3. Evolutionary psychologists will tell you that when people experience economic anxiety
column14: they often blame other tribes for the resource problems they helped to cause themselves. If you feel anxious about having to pay twice as much for natural gas or gasoline as you did a couple years ago
column15: look in the mirror for the reason instead of blaming caricatures from the Right's demonology

column1: The book is readable.  The pacing is pretty good.  Some of the scenes are pretty good.  The basic plot:  Dr. Victor Frank is a fertility and genetics genius and leads a world-class fertility and research company.  He and his wife decide to use in vitro fertilization to have a second child.  Dr. Frank is unable to restrain himself from tinkering with the embryo's genetic makeup and developmental schedule.  His secret experimentation results in a super-intelligent son
column2: VJ.  Unfortunately
column3: VJ's super intelligence comes with a complete amorality and pandemonium ensues.  Heavy-handed allusions
column4: too-obvious foreshadowing
column5: and a conclusion that is projected from chapter one are all problems.  There are plot holes you could drive a truck through.  Characterization is extremely simple
column6: character development is non-existent
column7: and the plot twists are too simple and obvious to be very enjoyable.  The basic premise of a super-intelligent amoral murdering drug-lord is not that original.  Now make him three years old when he kicks off his murdering spree by offing his own brother and
column8: well
column9: let's just say that it's not particularly credible.  By the time he's five he's bio-engineering lethal and infectious cancers in a genetics lab he assembled from stolen equipment?  I'm just not buying it.  Although the science and medicine are explained pretty well
column10: they're just not used in a credible way.  Final analysis:  There are many better things to read

This book seems to me to be another hoax of the type which appeared during the years following WWII.  The "diary" is written like a novel
column2: with plenty of dialogue. The book focuses on rape and seems to have been written to appeal to prurient curiosity.  It just doesn't ring true.  For example
column3: near the end
column4: the author writes that she gave her diaries to her former sweetheart to read.  "'What's this supposed to mean?' he asked
column5: pointing to 'Schdg.'  I had to laugh:  'Schandung
column6: '--of course--rape."  Oh yes
column7: Ha Ha
column8: very funny.  I'm sure the mass rapes of the German women after the fall of Berlin were just a hoot
column9: especially to those who experienced it.  No wonder the book met with hostility and criticism when it was first published in 1954--the book definitely demeans the horror of the experience the Berlin women survived.    The true identity of the author--"Anonymous"--has never been known.  Doubts over the authenticity of this "diary" have dogged the book since it was first published.  In the Introduction
column10: it states that "...experts on personal documents from the period have confirmed that the diary's transcript is original and completely genuine."  Now that's hilarious!  Just how did they confirm that--carbon dating???  I'm just glad I didn't buy the book. I borrowed it from the Library yesterday and I can return it there today.  I wouldn't want to put money in the pockets of anyone associated with profiting in this disrespectful way off of the true-life tragedies of victims of WWII

column1: This is the worst
column2: most depressing piece of fiction I have ever read.  There is no real protoganist and not one singular character worthy of admiration--and after a while
column3: their actions just become inexplicable.  The author's soul must truly be an ugly one to have devoted so much time and energy to using his mind to generate so many casual acts of evil throughout the book.  It starts out promising but by the time you get to about halfway through the book or so you get a nagging sense that your very own soul might be sucked out of you and permanently stolen by the heart of Neil Gaiman's darkness or one of his minions.  Additionally
column4: the characters' motivations change like the shifting sands
column5: nothing they do makes any real sense except some inexplicable movement towards doing greater and more evil en masse like some sort of coagulating bacteria or disease.  What is so creepy about this book is the casualness of it all.  Unlike some of Stephen King's work (ie: The Stand)
column6: there is absolutely no redeeming thread here--no rallying or marshalling the troops to combat the emerging evil.  It's evil in evil vs. evil surrounded by evil.  All I can say is that this book is ugly
column7: ugly
column8: ugly.  At least writers like Joyce Carol Oats and Joseph Conrad's intentions when writing about such things is to effectively demonstrate the ill effects of such darkness
column9: but to make heroes of characters one should avoid is unconscionable.  The choices the supposed protoganist makes make no sense--and you do root for  him in the very beginning but you find he is just like one of them after all.  I suspended my doubt and disbelief as long as I could but finally became so incensed by the audacity of both the literary critics and the author to pass this off as excellence
column10: I literally stopped mid-sentence and chose to never read this author's work again.  It's a shame too because he has allied himself in other incarnations with a truly gifted artist
column11: Dave McKean
column12: who maybe hasn't completely gone over to the dark side like Neil has.  His association with Dave McKean is the only reason I even opened-up the book--and maybe a little because the title intrigued me.  But it's unfortunate that the industry rewards "clever" works such as Mr. Gaiman's with undue praise.  I've never so strongly disliked a book.  Have you ever found yourself getting angry because you felt robbed or duped by a book?  Well
column13: don't believe the hype
column14: this is the one to throw in the trash or disintegrate with X-men eyeball laserbeams before all your humanity is sucked out of you

column1: In 1990 Bill Bryson set out to "do Europe". He says that his motivation was to relive his experiences from tours in Europe in 1972 and 1973 when he was a young student wandering around Europe with a backpack.  In reality it seems as if the primary reason for Bill Bryson to do this trip was so that he could then write a funny book about the trip.  "Neither Here Nor There" is
column2: in fact
column3: a very funny book
column4: at least in the beginning. Bill Bryson can describe situations in a very humorous way
column5: and he's willing to make fun of himself
column6: as well as everything around him.  Unfortunately
column7: after a while the humor wears thin. Then it wears very thin. Then you begin to dissect the humor
column8: and realize that you've been had.  Bill Bryson's method of traveling is to emulate the kind of tourism we all like to ridicule. He typically arrives by train in a new city in the evening. He has no hotel reservation so he has to spend time finding a hotel that is not really what he wanted. He sees "the sights" that one is supposed to see in that city. He makes no effort to get in touch with the local people
column9: to learn about their lives
column10: or to understand their country and society. He spends typically 2-3 days in each city and then goes to work on figuring out how to get to the next city or country on his list
column11: which often leads to further complications.  This is obviously not the way to travel if you're writing a travel book. Nobody in their right mind would want to read about this kind of traveling.   But Bill Bryson is not writing a travel book
column12: he's writing a funny book
column13: and he has a sure-fire recipe:  1. Do things in problematic ways
column14: and then make fun of all the trials and tribulations that result.  2. Mix in lots of flashbacks to the trips of your youth
column15: with much juvenile humor related to the drives that young men are so driven by.  3. Feign incomprehension about everything foreign and satirize everything that is unfamiliar.  4. Make funny remarks intended to reinforce national prejudices.  This last type of humor can be especially tiring. Here are a few examples to illustrate what I mean:  "Let's face it
column16: the French Army couldn't beat a girls' hockey team." (pg 32)  "The (German) women still don't shave their armpits. ... They all look so beautiful and stylish
column17: and then they lift up their arms and there's a Brillo pad hanging there." (pg 91)  "In Norway
column18: three people and a bottle of beer is a party; in Sweden the national sport is suicide." (pg 97)  "But the most preposterous law of all
column19: a law so pointless as to scamper along the outer reaches of the surreal
column20: is the Swedish one that requires motorists to drive with their headlights on during the daytime." (pg 110)  "I love the way the Italians park. You turn any street corner in Rome and it looks as if you've just missed a parking competition for blind people." (pg 123)  In conclusion
column21: if you're someone who "did Europe" in your youth and you want to relive fond memories in a humorous way
column22: then you may well like this book. Most other readers will probably start out laughing
column23: then smiling
column24: then wondering why the jokes seem to have lost their appeal
column25: and finally ending up wishing they'd picked a real travel book or a real humorous book.  Rennie Petersen  PS. Just for the record

column1: before i began writing this review
column2: i surfed the internet looking for reviews from other readers.  90% of the reviews i read began or ended similarly: i am a ____teen year old girl.  having only gotten through 150 pages of this book before calling it quits
column3: i wasn't surprised to learn that so many young women gravitated towards this book. after all
column4: the novel's protagonist is just such a teenage girl.  however
column5: this fact is more than a little bit troubling because astrid is not someone you'd want your daughter/sister/niece/cousin/etc to identify with. it's also troubling because when so many people
column6: both younger and older
column7: hail 'white oleander' as some sort of literary masterpiece
column8: even going so far as to compare it to nabakov's 'lolita.' this is a horrifying book
column9: not necessarily for the story's content (which is equally horrifying)
column10: but for it's plot
column11: execution
column12: characterization
column13: and particularly its ham-fisted writing.  to be sure
column14: this is a book written for the oprah generation and reflects the 'oprah-fication' of literature. the novel's problems are so many
column15: that i simply won't have time to address them all.  however
column16: i will address some of them:   1) astrid.  the novel's protagonist
column17: a fourteen year old girl
column18: is a thoroughly contradictory character.  some people have written that astrid is not your 'average' teenage girl and that she is 'gifted.'  if she were such a girl
column19: i would expect much more of her.  that's the least of the problems
column20: however.  i'm not a psychologist nor have i ever been shot
column21: but i suspect any fourteen year old girl who's mother was sent to prison for murder
column22: offered herself sexually to a man three times her age
column23: is shot by her first foster mother
column24: performs oral sex on a boy in exchange for 1/2 bag of marijuana would be severly emotionally disturbed and troubled.  astrid
column25: however
column26: seems to care less that she herself was nearly murdered
column27: instead she focuses on and longs her sexual encounters with ray. remember
column28: this is a fourteen year old girl.  any credibility astrid has a narrator is blown early on because no one who's gone through her experiences would be in as good as shape as she is. it also discredits her as a character
column29: and with a discredited character
column30: the novel doesn't stand a chance. think about a fourteen year old girl you know. now imagine her beaten
column31: shot
column32: mother in prison for murder
column33: sexually loose (some may argue ray took advantage of her
column34: but remember
column35: astrid was the one who approached ray and when he said no
column36: astrid was the one who dropped her clothes)
column37: and yearning for a lover three times her age. it simply wouldn't happen.    2) unfortunately
column38: the plot fitch drops astrid is pretty much by the numbers.  i have trouble with any novel where the plot is advanced by a series of tragedies or dire circumstances.  more often than not
column39: it's a gimmick (or crutch) inexperienced writers rely on when realistic ideas for authentic plots run thin ('the kite runner' suffered similar fate).  read joan didion or toni morrison (or steinbeck) and how see how they use tragedy--it's real
column40: honest
column41: and most importanly believable.  most of the 'white oleander's' is simply too unrealistic.  3)  the prose is borderline comical.  i was awe-struck to read how many people have praised fitch's prose.  fitch's use of similie is so overdone and forced that it slows the narrative down to a cumbersome pace.  similes should be used judiciously and flow naturally. fitch
column42: on the other hand
column43: find it's necessary to inject as many as four or five similies in just about every paragraph
column44: and most of them just ring false and forced.  the 'white' metaphor is also an unfortunate victim.  count the number of times fitch uses 'white' to describe astrid
column45: ingrid
column46: clothes
column47: food
column48: dishes
column49: the sky
column50: etc
column51: etc
column52: etc.  she beats the 'white' metaphor into holy submission and never really allows the reader to discover for him or herself underlying metaphors.  the majority of the book is over-described
column53: and so many of the descriptions are flowery and self-indulgent
column54: as if fitch is trying to prove to her readers that she's a capable and talented writer.  the sex scenes
column55: in particular
column56: are dreadful.  i don't want to read how a fourteen year old remembers every graphic detail of performing oral sex on a middle-aged man.  it's too much. way too much.  a 14 year old girl who's performed oral sex on a man is not going to long for it again. i can tell you that.  furthermore: at one point astrid sees a shiny convertible
column57: compares it to a man
column58: and imagines herself climaxing while laying on its hood; during her encounter with ray
column59: she describes the act as riding a horse through the surf.  and those are just the sex scenes.  also
column60: fitch refers to one man's hair as 'balding.'  hair
column62: can't bald.  scalps can bald.  hair cannot bald.  these comparisons seem better fit for 3.99 romance novels at the supermarket checkout.  fitch also seems intent on stringing together a bunch of pretty words in hopes of making pretty sentences.  unfortunately
column63: this does not work.  pretty words don't necessarily make pretty sentences the same way pretty notes don't necessarily make pretty songs.  fitch's prose works much the same way thomas kincaide's 'art' works -- it's looks pretty
column64: but there's really no substance to it.  it's also much like 'legends of the fall' -- sure it looks great
column65: but all you get when you strip the prettiness away
column66: you end up with little more than a soap opera.  she would do well to focus more on advancing plot than affecting a poetic or lyrical voice.  4) the characters and uniformly cliched and poorly drawn.  astrid's mother is the self-absorbed
column67: feminist poet.  her first foster mother is a bible-thumping floozy; her stepmother's boyfriend is the object of astrid's desires
column68: even though he's more then three times her age; the second stepmother is demanding and her husband is quiet and reserved; and of course we have the 'hooker with a heart of gold' who takes astrid under her wing.   in fact
column69: the professional prostitute is the only emotionally stable and 'nice' character in the entire 150 pages that i read.   what's fitch trying to say?  maybe something
column70: maybe nothing.  but fitch's character's seem born straight out of some pseudo-intellectual writer's workshop.  any editor worth his or her salt should've have caught and corrected these flaws.  the fact that the editor(s) didn't
column71: while i'd like to think it was out of sheer laziness
column72: is  proof that american literature as a whole is in serious decline and that unrealistic plots and characters = big dollars.  and as i mentioned earlier
column73: the fact that so many people hail this book as high literature signals trouble for the future of the american letters.  i know most people will probably vote this 'unhelpful' simply because i disagree on the book's merits.  that's fine. i
column75: strongly object to this novel on the whole.  i'm sure that as most of the teenage girls grow up and mature
column76: they'll see 'white oleander' for what is is: an immature
column77: adolescent novel masquerading as high literature. and i sincerely hope that no more young women identify with astrid in anyway.  that's the real tragedy

column1: This book should be approached with caution.  If you can get past the "flaunt" of Dr. Pepe's fabulous life and the fact that she would dare to show off how much better she is doing in front of other MS sufferers
column2: some that are in wheelchairs and probably wish they too could twirl on their high heels
column3: then perhaps you should remember that this is one woman's opinion.  Her advice will not cure you.  It is unbelievable that someone would tout the old wives' tales (bee vemon and dental fillings) as part of a path to successfully overcoming the symptoms of MS.  If there were any significance to either of these woudn't we know it?  After all
column4: people have been trying them for decades now.  The use of CAM (complimentary and alternative) therapies can be beneficial.  A very good neurologist advised me that a combination of proper exercise
column5: yoga
column6: good nutrition
column7: a daily multi-vitamin and trying to remain generally positive was best.  I have to say he was right.  After six years of constant MS problems and attacks
column8: I adopted a healthier lifestyle
column9: including regular exercise
column10: and have been relapse free for almost four years.  (If you are wondering
column11: I do take one of the ABCR drugs as well.)  A better alternative to buying this book would be to get Nancy Davis' book.  It is titled
column12: "Lean on Me: Ten powerful steps to taking back your life after your diagnosis".  It is more realistic and more helful to the average person that this book.

column1: I gather Mr Seagrave is a journalist
column2: and not a trained historian. His sloppiness shows on the cover (She was not China's last Empress) and in the author's note which claims China had three 'reigning empresses'. This last shows clearly that Mr Seagrave doesn't understand the subject. It's difficult to know what exactly he means by the term. Ci Xi was an Empress who had an remarkable degree of influence. Other Empresses had varying degrees of influence. Ci Xi was not a 'reigning empress' if that means she was formally the monarch. Only one woman
column3: Wu Zetian
column4: ever held that position
column5: and she should rightly be called Emperor
column6: not Empress
column7: as there was no concept of 'Empress' in imperial China other than as the consort of an Emperor. Writing a special note in the front of the book to lump these three together and imply that they all held the same position
column8: presumably in order to emphasise the remarkable power that Ci Xi held
column9: irreparably undermines Mr Seagrave's credibility.

column1: I've occasionally enjoyed William F. Buckley's Blackford Oakes novels

 I read this book as part of a book discussion group I had joined and it was so wretchedly lackluster it proved to be the death knell of me ever going back to the group. This book was half-baked, boring, and grievously devoid of even the tiniest bit of interest. I can't even give it credit for having any sort of vocabulary beyond the comprehension of an average twelve year old. The characters were so flat that I didn't even finish it. Later I heard from the other book discussion members even the title was a let down as Morgan never actually passed away (`twould have been a fitting end though - much like converting a testy horse into glue, something of actual use.) I've never read any of Anne Tyler's books but after this little gem I doubt I'll ever pick up another.

 Can Quilleren and his cats figure out who is responsible for the fraud, where the president of the company is, and where all that money went? Qwilleran is a columnist in his local paper.  Everyone is in love with his column because he writes so well.  But when Floyd Trevelyan hosts a party train ride costing $500 a ticket, and says he will give the money to a charity for a college, but then things happen.  Someone calls an audit on him and he goes missing with the money.  When a dog is killed and a body is turned up suspicions rise.  Where is Floyd Trevelyan? Where is the money? Who killed the dog and the man? But then when clues pop up, and his cats Koko and Yum Yum since of mystery help, Qwilleran figures out that Floyd's new secretary killed Floyd and took the money, and the other deaths were from his son and another man in a feud.  At the end Qwilleran figures out that the secretary was really a man, and tells the cop they are looking for the wrong name. He then reads to his cats. I didn't really like this book.  There were way too many characters to keep track with.  The story line didn't go like a normal mystery.  Also, it didn't explain what happened afterwards.  In this book there were tons of characters.  So much that I couldn't even keep track of all of them.  You had to remember the whole Trevelyan family the dad, the mom, the son, and the sister.  You had to remember all of Quillerens friends, and also all his business partners and staff.  There were still many of other key people also.  Such as at the end of the book he started naming all these names that figured out the mystery and I didn't know who was who.  This book was not like a normal mystery, but not in a good way.  The whole book was like just a section of their life.  Nothing interesting happened.  There wasn't that made you wondering what was going on, or what was going to happen.  Sure there were little things you wondered about but nothing big.  This made it very boring to read this book.  It didn't even seem like a mystery until the last five pages.  Quilleren figures out the whole mystery, or at least turns the little one there was into a big one. But then after he figures it out, he basically does nothing about it.  This book left you on a cliffhanger.  It didn't explain what happened at the end.  It just stopped at Quilleran reading the book to his cat.  It didn't say if they fount the girl which was actually a man, it didn't tell what happened to all the people and if they found the body.  Also nothing ever happened between Quilleren and Patty.  It also never said where his friend went too.  So really you didn't learn anything at the end except for when he solved the mystery, but other than that, you were clueless.   This book sort of disappointed me.  There were some good things, but mostly bad things.  I wouldn't recommend it to other readers.  It didn't have bad writing, but the story was not well written.   
 This book was sooooooo boring.  I kept reading it only in the misguided hope that it would get more interesting.  It has an unlikeable and annoying main character.  The writing style is overly simple, and literally NOTHING happens.  The reason that she and her mother fall out" is never explained.  Don't waste your time.

column1: This book is a very easy to read seemingly well documented work but it will not provide the reader with Thomas Jefferson in historical context. If your interest is in what Mr. Jefferson accomplished during his life and the many great achievements that he participated in on behalf the formation of the United States I would pass up this work.  If your interest lies in his carnal side and his personal sexual history this might be more your speed.  Had I known this was the piece of fluff that it turned out to be I would not have wasted my money on this work.  This book would probably be a good basis for daytime TV couch potato fare.  It is hardly a good work of historical content and most likely would have been rejected by any Masters level thesis committee.  Most of this book could be condensed into one chapter. On a number of occasions Mr Halliday lets his own personal political bias color his image of Mr. Jefferson pushing this work even further from the vein of relevant history. I picked up this work based upon the recommendations on the inside cover.  I have always been impressed with the historical works of Mr. Ambrose but I believe that there must have been more to his review.

column4: he offers up predictions.  Big mistake.  This guy bases his forecasts on Fibonacci numbers and so-called Elliott "wave counts."   He labels all market patterns so that they fit the preordained Elliott Wave 5-up
column5: 3-down pattern.  If you see more or fewer waves than he does in any given market move
column6: you just don't understand that there can only be 5 waves to the top of a bull market.  He's imposing his theory on the market
column7: but surprisingly enough
column8: the market doesn't care.  It does whatever it wants
column9: in however many waves it wants
column10: and Bob has been very frustrated at the market's aberrant behavior lately.  He got lucky early in his career
column11: but it seems he's been fairly consistently getting the market wrong since missing the '87 crash.    Any superstitution can "seem" to work if you only look at its happenstance apparent accuracies and disregard its abundant failures.  Keep looking for certain numbers of waves and Fibonacci ratios and you'll find what you're looking for.  Pick any set of numbers or patterns or wave counts
column12: and you'll find those too.  The market doesn't care about any of those things
column13: though.  It's nothing more than an aggregation of billlions of individual choices
column14: which are influenced by an infinite number of factors none of us can ever understand fully.  University studies of various investing methods have found that Elliott Wave
column15: like most
column16: is no better than random stock selection.   If Prechter had chosen the random method
column17: he and his followers would at least have a good chance of keeping pace with the market.  Unfortunately
column18: he has been getting everything from the Dow
column19: to oil (he thought it was going to $10)
column20: to gold (he didn't think it could break $400)
column21: to deflation (the "deflation" scare ended shortly after this book came out) WRONG in the past couple of years.  He apparently STILL believes that the Dow will go to 400 (not 4
column22: 000 but FOUR HUNDRED) because his charts tell him it should (they've been telling him that since about 1990
column23: actually).  Prechter doesn't understand demographics or economics or markets or the monetary system
column24: all of which render "Dow 400" among the goofiest of forecasting absurdities -- unless you believe a giant asteroid will hit and wipe out two thirds of the population (I don't think Prechter is counting on that).  Our debt-heavy economy may have a significant crisis soon
column25: perhaps by the end of the decade.  It will most likely be spurred on by inflation and rising interest rates.  But it's not happening now and it's not happening in the way this author has been prematurely forecasting for over a decade.  This book came out near the bottom of the 2000-2002 stock bear market
column26: just in time for a reader to short stocks as they began a new bull market.  How typical.  While promoting the book
column27: Prechter said it was "definite" that stocks would "crash" in 2003.  He said that 2003 would be "the best year yet" for bears (short sellers).  Late into 2003
column28: when it was clear that the market had proven him wrong
column29: Prechter declared on a radio show that by the end of 2004
column30: the Dow would "certainly" fall below 5
column31: 000.  Wrong again!  Since his Fibonacci turn dates and Elliott wave counts fail to portend the future
column32: maybe next he'll tell us he's found the secret code to the stock market from the text count of Nostradamus' writings.  Bob Prechter couldn't call the market if it was listed in the Yellow Pages.  This guy couldn't time the market if you gave him a stopwatch.  He's throwing out guesses and misleading people by describing them as "definite" and "certain."  He's either a liar or a true believer in his own irrational superstitions.  In either case
column33: he's not credible.  Here's all you really need to know: Buy dividend stocks.  Buy short-term bonds.  Buy gold.  Hang on to them.  Do that and you'll do better than you will trying to follow the prognostications of market gurus.  Plus
column34: you'll have a lot more time to devote to family
column35: fun
column36: and productive activities

column1: I wonder how long it will be before Frost's literary stock is devalued as much as it deserves to be. These are trite and banal poems that do not ring true or sincere. Frost seems distant from both his poems and the reader. What he has to say is obvious and unoriginal. How he says it is on the level of a hallmark greeting card at its best; at its worst
column2: it is no better than a limerick. Posthumous revelations about his horrific cruelty to others and his shrewd creation/manipulation of his celebrity image as the New England farmer-poet only confirm that there was something seriously wrong with this man and his poems that an earlier generation missed. How earlier generations could find genius in such obvious observations is astounding. Bad poetry from a twisted man

column1: The exercises in the book seem to be purposefully difficult.  Is this to discourage prospective copyeditors or so that Einsohn can show off her years of experience?  In order to be instructional
column2: the explanations should fully cover the concepts that one will be tested on in the exercises.  Anyone who can read should be able to read the text and then successfully complete the exercises.  This is basic to good instructional design. Instead
column3: in the exercises
column4: Einsohn throws in the exceptions to the rules or tests on concepts only hinted at in the text.  Einsohn reminds me of the bad teachers we have all experienced at one time or another who get satisfaction from confusing students by talking around a subject instead of teaching the subject directly.  Success of students is not the goal of these teachers.  There are many finer points in copyediting
column5: but there are sets of rules governing them all.  It should be a simple matter to present the rules and then test the student on those rules

column1: Elmore Leonard is one of the more respected of popular contemporary authors
column2: and deservingly so.  He has a wonderful ear for dialogue and the impressive ability to both generate plot and develop characters through it.  What many authors may describe in several paragraphs or pages
column3: Leonard does in a few lines of dialogue.  As such
column4: his books are tremendously quick and enjoyable reads.  However
column5: 'Be Cool' is not one of his best.  The concept is interesting enough: a sequel.  And not just that
column6: but a sort of metafictional work poking fun at the whole idea of sequels.  Chili Palmer returns
column7: trying to get his foot in the door of the music industry.  As always
column8: the protagonist is surrounded by an odd assortment of hitmen
column9: cons
column10: and scattered goofballs.  However
column11: when reading 'Be Cool' I couldn't shake the feeling that the book was rushed.  Many of the character (the cop
column12: the gangsta rapper) are scarcely developed at all (the latter
column13: in particular
column14: could have been a rich source of satire).  Also
column15: the ending seemed rushed
column16: as well.  Leonard seemed to be racing towards it without building up much tension.  The reader reaches the last page and wonders what was the point of the second half of the book.  I'd always recommend Elmore Leonard as a quick
column17: enjoyable
column18: "beach" read.  However
column19: go with something else of his instead of 'Be Cool.

column1: I found this book totally impractical and a waste of money for cooking in a small RV.   It might be okay for the person with a 40 foot motorhome with a complete kitchen and all the comforts of home.  Many of the recipes contain ingredients that I don't even keep at home.  Access to perishables and fresh produce is assumed although the authors mention cooking in the middle of the Mohave Desert in the Introduction. Who takes cloth napkins on a camping trip (and where do you wash them)?  A much more useful book is "Easy RV Recipes: Easy Recipes for the Traveling Cook" by Ferne Holmes.
I love history
column2: but it has to have a decent narrative.  This book does have history
column3: but a good narrative appears sporadically.  While better than scholarly writing
column4: this just won't keep you glued to your seat.  If you can push yourself to finish you deserve a pat on the back
column5: but don't buy this book if you need to be enthralled

column1: Actually not going to be kind........... What a load of RUBBISH
Western Michigan University Professor John Blacking (1928-1990) prefaces his intended answer to the titular question
column2: How Musical is Man?
column3: with the qualification that this work - originally printed in 1973 - is "not a scholarly study
column4: so much as an attempt to reconcile my experiences." With this in mind
column5: the reader should not be surprised to find a self-indulgent speculative which walks a fine line between narrowly focused ethnomusicologic comparative (Western society versus the Venda tribe of South Africa) and a loosely organized philosophical reflection. Ultimately
column6: Blacking presents an indictment of Western culture with relatively rare bibliographic references. The absence of an index or collective bibliography
column7: combined with the restricted assessment
column8: limits the text's use as a convenient or scholarly reference. Nevertheless
column9: it retains value as a time capsule of perspective from a pioneering ethnomusicological researcher. Blacking divides his discussion into four sections: I. Humanly Organized Sound; II. Music and Society and Culture; III. Culture and Society in Music; IV. Soundly Organized Humanity. Throughout
column10: he raises further questions crucial to answering the overriding inquiry. He describes the first three chapters as an attempt to show how research in ethnomusicology may resolve myriad related questions. In the final chapter he endeavors to address why answering the question is essential. Somehow he never quite answers the question satisfactorily.  After an enigmatic opening with what appears to be a feeble attempt at numerologic humor ("Ethnomusicology ... It's seven syllables do not give it any advantage over the pentasyllabic `musicology.'")
column11: Blacking's first chapter positions music as a species-specific sonic phenomenon we are compelled to organize and argues the need to look for patterns and relationships between musical and cultural behaviors. Blacking turns constantly
column12: if monoptically
column13: to his own experiences with the Venda tribe. Blacking goes on to insist the question of man's musicality cannot be answered without first understanding the processes of cause and effect
column14: such as the issue of who performs
column15: sings and listens to music and why. Here he also aptly suggests the social setting may at times even supersede the music in a culture's perception and that it is essential to listen with the appropriate cultural ears. Again he turns largely to the Venda tribe for examples and even provides an illustrated calendar of Venda musical practice and an complicated diagram of musical and social relationships in the Venda society. Ironically
column16: while stepping on and off his societal soapbox
column17: Blacking manages to critique the presumptive arrogance of narrowly focused Western musicologists and condemn the practice of apartheid
column18: but he inherently accepts the Venda tribe's mutilation of women in their annual season of female circumcision. Contradictions abound. The book contains several confusing segues into self-indulgent recollections and intermittent non sequiturs
column19: such as in the ultimate paragraph: "Even falling in love may be more significant as a cognitive activity in which learned categories are realigned
column20: than as an exertion of the sex organs or a hormonal reaction." For a scholarly tome suitable for extended practical shelf life from this author
column21: one might do well to forgo his philosophical prattling for his actual research originally printed in 1967
column22: Venda Children's Songs: A Study in Ethnomusicological Analysis (Chicago and London: University of Chicago Press
column23: 1995)  G. Galv

column1: There isn't anything new to Machen's basic argument: that liberal Christians are not true Christians. Fundamentalists have been saying the same thing for years. Machen simply supplements such black-and-white non-thinking with pseudointellectual arguments.  What Machen really seems to be saying is that because liberal Christians don't agree with conservative and/or fundamentalist theology
column2: or go along with legalism and strict adherence to doctrine
column3: they are not Christians.  There is so much more to Christianity than rules. At least there should be. I think that if God wanted us to strictly follow rules and regulations instead of enter into a personal relationship with Him
column4: He would have created a government structure.   I also don't buy the assertion that we should strictly adhere to traditonal doctrine. There was once a time when the church persecuted scientists for simply suggesting that the sun rotated around the earth! Doctrine has been used in that way for centuries upon centuries to shut people up and force them into conformity.  People should
column5: at least
column6: be allowed to have their own set of beliefs
column7: within reason. I am very uncomfortable with any organization
column8: whether religious or otherwise
column9: forcing its adherents to conform to their doctrine without allowing for any "wiggle room". such situations leave too much room for persecution of those who don't necessarily agree with a point of doctrine.  It's also rather anti-intellectual. Traditional doctrine is not
column10: after all
column11: infallible. Traditional doctrine may say that the world is made of snow. That doesn't mean it's true; it only means that past generations have been horribly wrong with their science.  There are some doctrines to which we all adhere - an example is the deity of Jesus. But many doctrines are open to debate
column12: and they should remain that way.  Finally
column13: I question Machen's assertion that liberal Christians adhere to a separate religion. If a liberal Christian believes in one true God
column14: and that Jesus is His son
column15: and that He died on the cross for the world's sins
column16: and assuming that Machen is correct in his judgment
column17: then to what religion does this hypothetical liberal Christian adhere? I fail to see how having valid questions about hell
column18: or the Bible
column19: or the creation of the world
column20: or other such issues are absolute deal-breakers that indicate that a person is not a True Christian.  It seems that Machen subscribes to a quite narrow definition of Christianity
column21: into which many people won't fit. The Bible is quite clear that everyone - regardless or who they are
column22: what they've done or any other factor - are open to salvation. Surely liberal Christians such as myself apply as well

column1: This is truly a disappointing book.  It starts incredibly slowly and I found it very hard to become interested in the plot.  Another disappointment is Koontz's recycling of elements from other novels: (1) plucky
column2: highly intelligent disabled girl (the young female protagonist in "The Hideaway" had almost identical deformities and personality)
column3: (2) devoted
column4: super-powered canine companions
column5: (3) bad guys driving around in ultra pimped-out RVs
column6: and (4) evil bioethicists.  The Leilani character is patently ridiculous.  She conveniently has a genius IQ
column7: but that does not make the absurdly adult manner in which she speaks any more believable.  I found it so disconcerting as to detract from the plot.  Koontz clearly has trouble writing for children
column8: and this book is no exception.  Almost all the children featured in his books are either autistic/MR or genius wunderkinds; the latter
column9: however
column10: does not justify his habit of making smart children talk like genius adults.  Dean heaps the hardships on poor Leilani
column11: with all the subtlety of an episode of Walker
column12: Texas Ranger.  In case you miss the anvils
column13: you are supposed to really
column14: really like her and fear for her safety.  I don't know how or where Dean Koontz learned about bioethics
column15: but he has a terribly misguided view of the field
column16: taking an extreme sect of it to represent the main viewpoint of the field.  Further
column17: he states multiple times that these eugenic bioethics principles are being taught to medical students at major universities (who will have to pay for their involvement with evil bioethics) -- as a medical student
column18: I can assure you that this is patently untrue.  That Koontz could be so off-base on a topic that directly relates to the central motive is disconcerting and makes an already weak book even harder to swallow.  The final issue is Koontz's near-deification of dogs
column19: particularly Golden Retrievers
column20: which is a common motif in his more recent works.  It is ridiculous and unintentionally funny to an almost painful degree.  His obsession with dogs and their mystical powers borders on the psychotic (and I like dogs).  This novel probably features the most egregious example of Koontz's tendency to create overly sappy
column21: sugary-sweet endings.  Dean Koontz has written many books better than this one.  Spend your money on one of his stronger efforts

column1: The title of the book certainly was a great inducement to buy the book.  Thinking that it would be an informed commentary on key elements of Bush's character
column2: I purchased this book and eagerly awaited its arrival.    Starting off well
column3: the author lays out what he purports to be the architecture of a meaningful and detailed analysis.  Then
column4: sadly it degenerates into a self serving diatribe filled with epithets and derogatory terms.    Whether or not you support the President
column5: any credible review of his actions from a psychiatry perspective should at least appear unbiased.  Not the case here.  Mr. Frank quickly descends into child like name calling and remarks that should never come from a professional.  He cites theories from others that indicate it is impossible to accurately apply a diagnosis without lengthy study
column6: then in the next few paragraphs violates that premise by applying the very diagnosis he earlier claimed was impossible.  Finally
column7: (and I have learned my lesson here) the final words of the book are a call for Bush's impeachment.  What that has to do with an unbiased psychological analysis I have no idea.  I now will read the final paragraph from any book Mr. Frank writes to understand his motivation before sharng my hard earned money with him.  Unless you are a closed minded rabid Bush hater
column8: this book will not appeal to you.  If you are of such ilk
column9: just rewards are yours for the reading

column2: to put it very mildly
column3: does not have a high opinion of the Old Testament.  But Thompson has managed to write something even worse.  It is one thing to point out that Biblical stories of the Exodus and the conquest of Israel by Joshua are contradicted by archaeological evidence (they are).  It is quite another to throw out genuine archaeological evidence as well as any connections to Biblical stories from the Book of Judges onwards
column4: as though neither people nor history existed back then!    If folks want to say that there were ancient Israelites back in the 13th century BC
column5: and have some evidence for it (including
column6: say
column7: Merneptah's Stele
column8: which appears to refer to them explicitly)
column9: then right or wrong
column10: that's scholarship.  If others want to say that the actual Israelites did not appear until the 12th or 11th century BC
column11: and present some evidence for that (including explaining the Stele
column12: of course)
column13: well
column14: that's scholarship as well.  I'd refer interested readers to works such as "The First Historians" by Baruch Halpern (1988)
column15: "The Archaeology of the Land of Israel" by Yohanan Aharoni (1978) and "Who Were the Israelites and Where Did They Come From?" by William Dever (2003).  Thompson
column16: however
column17: is an anti-scholar.  He knows that people existed from the 13th through the 3rd centuries BC.  He knows there's enormous amounts of corroborating evidence about what those people were like.  And he's out to denounce anyone who says anything about them
column18: no matter what they say!  It's simply ridiculous.    The claim that there were no such people as the ancient Israelites is not scholarly unless it is backed up by some rather striking evidence.  Thompson has nothing of the sort.    This guy is worse than the Bible-is-truth fundamentalists.  At least
column19: those who believe the accounts in the Old Testament will get some of the later history right
column20: once in a while.  Thompson

column1: Reviewer Shalom Freedman lists a series of major differences between the Israeli government and various U.S. administrations.  The fact that they occurred is undeniable.  Many more could be added.  For example
column2: both the Truman and Eisenhower Adminsitrations refused to sell any weapons to Israel
column3: not even those of a defensive nature.  Jimmy Carter was certainly no friend of Israel and pressured Israel into giving up all of Sinai.  (As the winner of a war it did not seek
column4: Israel had every right to keep it or at least part of it.)  Bill Clinton interfered in Israel's internal electoral process in favor of the Labor Party and in opposition to the Likud party.   What is incredible is that the vast majority of readers found Friedman's review to be of no value.  That so many people do not wish to be confused with the facts is rather scary.

column1: It's a common belief that John Woo lost his way when he moved to Hollywood
column2: but in truth his career was always highly erratic even in his Hong Kong days. For every Better Tomorrow or The Killer on his resume there's at least one disappointment on the level of Bullet in the head.  On paper Bullet in the Head looks like John Woo's most ambitious and under-rated film
column3: but sadly it turns out to be an entirely derivative and largely ineffective shoot-em-up that blows its few good ideas in all the overkill. There's the germ of a good idea in its sprawling tale of three friends who skip the rioting Hong Kong of 1967 to make their fortune in the chaos of Vietnam
column4: but it's quickly lost amid the cartoon carnage - this is the kind of film where Woo will add a bomb disposal man having his arms blown off to the background of a romantic parting
column5: and that's one of the more subtle scenes. Clunking construction and wild leaps of logic abound (it's hard to take Jacky Cheung's cries of "Don't make me commit murder!" seriously after we've just seen him gun down thirty people) and the tragedy of Vietnam is reduced to the level of a video game in several over the top and largely uninvolving action scenes.   There are a few mildly effective moments
column6: such as Simon Yam's memorable introduction
column7: but the lasting impression is of a hack who has seen The Deer Hunter and The Killing Fields several times without ever really understanding them. Horrendously disappointing. No misjudged underappreciated lost masterpiece
column8: just a mess

column1: Having read "The Millionaire Next Door
column2:
as well as most if not all of the classics in this category, I expected life-altering experiences with this book.  There were too many statistics, and statistics that contradicted one another, not to mention generalizations about various subgroups that, try as I did, I had to put my copy down and use it at first for a door stop, then because the cover art is great, I decided leaving it on the coffee table makes a great conversation piece.  
 I've read many books of this genre, and this is so far the one I dislike the most. I'm not saying the author is a bad writer, she is very good at telling stories and sounds like a nice person. However, this book has very few accounts of real haunts. She considers dreams as real accounts or out-of-body experiences, which in my opinion are still just dreams. From the beginning it felt like she was expecting to find ghosts from day one and most of her perception seem like she truly wants to see something happen, like she's trying too hard. Also, she just assumes, also from day one, that the house is haunted by the last owner who just died. It seems like wishful thinking to me, I mean, it's an old house, it's bound be have many deaths in its history, and one can get really imaginative living in it.   I believe and like to read about the supernatural, but this book didn't convince me one bit 
 I want to preface my review by saying I consider myself to be pretty open minded, and when I read some of the other bad reviews before getting this book I thought to myself these people need to lighten up.  I have now read the book and am ready to admit I was wrong.    I read it, and I thought it was funny, but if this were going to be a tool to help teach my son about sex I could take him to a public bathroom and show him the drawings on the walls for free.  My goal is to start talking to my son about sex early, honestly, and using the correct names for body parts; to teach him that his body and sex are natural and beautiful; rather than a dirty secret to make vulgar jokes about.  This book does nothing to help me.  The premise of this book is that the two children teach the parents the facts of life, so if you would like to have a nine or ten year old teach your child the facts of life this is the book for you. If you would rather an adult explain it in a way a child can understand there are many other wonderful books out there, keep looking

 I had written a long review on this novel, but appearantly it vanished. She runs into the Lone Ranger..I mean Jake Tin Man" Dolan.  Jake Dolan has major trust issues and is written like a third-rate Jean Claud Van Damme role.  These two are convineatly sexually attracted to each other almost immediately
