Mr. Dennett's book demonstrates the ignorance
column2: irrationality
column3: and dishonesty  of humanists. Discussing the meaning of word materialsim
column4: Professor Dennett says:  "In its scientific or philosophical sense
column5: it refers to a theory that aspires to explain all the phenomena without recourse to anything immaterial--like a Cartesian soul
column6: or "ectoplasm"--or God. The standard negation of materialistic in the scientific sense is dualistic
column7: which maintains that there are two entirely different kinds of substance
column8: matter and ...whatever minds are supposedly made of." (p. 302)  Philosophers stopped believing in dualism a thousand years ago with the development of metaphysics. A modern view is that man is an indefinability that becomes conscious of its own existence.   The philosophy that God does not exist is not materialism
column9: it is naturalism. Materialism is the view that all that exists is matter. Materialists frequently say that free will is an illusion and that the experience of the existence of oneself is some kind of epiphenomena. (In a quote below
column10: you will see that Dennett puts free will in a list of things people belief in.)  It is not clear from the book whether Dennett is a materialist
column11: but he is certainly a naturalist. Concerning the proof of God's existence
column12: he trots out David Hume's "Who made God?" which is based on a misunderstanding of the principle of causality. I refer the reader to my personal website for my version of the proof.  Let's look at two quotes
column13: the first is at the end of the chapter "Belief in Belief" and the other at the beginning of the chapter "Morality and Religion":   "That is
column14: isn't it true that
column15: whether or not God exists
column16: religious belief is at least as important as the belief in democracy
column17: in the rule of law
column18: in free will? The very widespread (but far from universal) opinion is that religion is the bulwark of morality and meaning." (p. 245)  " Without the divine carrot and stick
column19: goes this reasoning
column20: people would loll about aimlessly or indulge their basest desires
column21: beak their promises
column22: cheat on their spouses
column23: neglect their duties
column24: and so on.  There are two well-known problems with this reasoning: (1) it doesn't seem to be true
column25: which is good news
column26: since (2) is is such a demeaning view of human nature." (p. 279)  In the first chapter
column27: he mentions "bulwark of morality" and "meaning." But in the second chapter
column28: he leaves out "meaning."  If our purpose in life is not to get to heaven
column29: what is our purpose is life?   Whether religion supports morality can be determined by observing whether there is a correlation of moral conduct with religious belief. Mr. Dennett makes such a correlation to the detriment of religion by citing the high divorce rate of fundamentalist Christians.  There are worse things than divorcing your spouse. Disingenuousness can be worse and can take the form of leaving unsaid what should have been said. Mr. Dennett should have explained why he did not discuss the idea that religion gives meaning to life.  The only miracle mentioned in Mr. Dennett's book is the Shroud of Turin
column30: which has on it a mysterious image of a crucified man.  Since no one claims to know how the image got there
column31: it can be called a miracle. However
column32: Mr. Dennett does not tell us anything about it. The reader is left to find out about the famous relic by looking it up on the internet.

column1: My reaction to this book was the eventual impetus to just go out and purchase other books on meditation because the style and approach of the author were so irksome to me. I bought it because of the simple eloquence of the cover and the title

column7: it's a real turn-off
column8: although fortunately for me I just resolved to look for other meditation books (I've been using the "Getting in the Gap" meditation most extensively
column9: and been trying to read a couple other books). There are a few reasons I wanted to learn how to meditate... one of them being the hope of maybe experiencing moments of deep insight or contact with something mystical or angelic
column10: and at one point the author actually more or less actually discourages this aspect of meditation. He specifically refers to the possibility of these types of experiences during meditation
column11: saying that you can just basically ignore it and keep going with the meditation
column12: because these aren't the important part of meditation. It would seem to me if you had a mystical experience during meditation it would be something important enough to pay attention to
column13: whether "real" or not.   This annoyed me
column14: but my disagreement with that view was not so much the problem
column15: as the consistent authoritarian and absolute style of his teachings on meditation. He seemed so focused on the shoulds and shouldn'ts of the whole discipline
column16: which to me in a way is sort of going against the whole notion of meditation
column17: and it made me put the book down. I did his first breathing exercise
column18: which was fine
column19: and I tried to go on with the book
column20: but the style of his teaching was too much for me. It was annoying because the cover looks so elegant and zen-like and then what was inside
column21: to me
column22: seemed at odds with that.   Basically
column23: if an an air of finality in an instructive book on meditation doesn't appeal to you

PEST CONTROL was my first book by Mr. Fitzhugh and 30 pages into it I decided it will probably be my last.  The plot outline--ordinary Joe too fixated on his entomological obsession to notice he's been accidentally mistaken for an international assassin--is an ingeniously set stage ripe for grand comedy.  Alas
column2: the curtain never rises above knee level.  The central events & conversations which must create the grand illusion on which the story hinges are unimaginative
column3: unconvincing
column4: and alas
column5: not very funny.  The story goes from there into an adolescent action slapstick
column6: full of too many hastily-created throwaway characters that mostly showcase the author's lack of descriptive power.  If ever a story cried out for an editor this it it.  His awful similes ("Their hearts were harder than trying to open an oyster with a wet bus ticket.") only look good compared to the juvenile imagination which chases the increasingly implausible plot into an oddly tedious crescendo of casual New York slaughter.  The final resolution tries to leap too many logical potholes to survive the crossing into epilogue intact.  The utter unreality of Fitzhugh's cartoonish world could have been a comedic asset if it were consistent
column7: but it doesn't just migrate as the pages wear on
column8: it gallops away
column9: leaving this reader wondering by the end why he didn't quit on page 30

column4: the long blond hair
column5: the body that does not exist on a woman after the ravages of chemotheraphy.  I can perfectly understand Mattel wanting to support breast cancer research and donate a portion of proceedes towards funding (and thank you for your generosity)
column6: but to do it under the guise of selling a "doll" which does not reflect the community of women who have experienced the challenges of recovery and survivorship...a doll which does not look like a survivor is literally painful and insulting!  Why doesn't this doll have a wig?  Why doesn't she have a breast removed?  Why doesn't she have a bra fitted with a form to mimic the shape of a breast?  What is wrong with reality? This frame looks great until you turn it on. The picture quality is less than stellar
column2: but that isn't what annoyed me about this frame. When you buy this frame don't expect to view your photos at the 16:9 ratio without some work in a photo manipulation program. What does that mean you ask? That means that your photos won't fill the entire screen in the 4:3 mode. You will have 2 black bars on either side of your images; This will not take advantage of the entire frame. If you switch to the 16:9 mode your images will stretch to the width of the frame
column3: making peoples faces distorted. I have a workaround for those who are familiar with image manipulation. See below.  The build quality of the frame is pretty good. If Mustek would fix the 16:9 problem and get a better quality screen
column4: this would be a nice little frame.  A little work is evolved setting up the pictures for the 16:9 ratio
column5: but I figured it out. 16:9 stretches the image
column6: making it look distorted. These steps compensate for the stretch and make your images appear normal. I set up a macro in Photoshop allowing me to do a batch in one click of the mouse. You will just need to keep an eye out on how it crops the image. Some of your images might be better served one at a time.   Start with an image that is 1024x768 in your image editing program.   1. Go to the image size menu and change the width of the image to 77% (or 788 pixels)   This will make the image look distorted. That is ok.   2. Then go to the canvas size menu and crop the height of the image to 77% (or 591 pixels)              The image is ready to save. You might want to save as in to another folder so you can go back to your original if needed.   3. Copy your edited images on to the flash card and insert into the frame

column1: This film pulls together all of the arguments in favor of wal-mart.  There is also a very interesting conclusion on the undeniable good work that the company did in summer 2005 in the Katrina-ravaged regions.  However
column2: none of the legitimate concerns of critics are given any thoughtful review.  I say this as a concerned conservative
column3: who wants to understand the enormous changes occuring in my country
column4: and not a liberal.  On the plus side
column5: it is hard to argue against the business model of wal-mart:  it offers everyday low prices
column6: which the company accomplishes by incredible and continual productivity gains - by some measures wal-mart is responsible for 25% of the productivity gains in the US due to its use of new technologies! - as well as vast scale economies in particular with globalisation.  Regardless of what critics say
column7: these factors are the basis of the company's success:  consumers chose to buy there because of the prices and convenience.  However
column8: this is the point when the film becomes disingenuous.  Anything that critics say is summarily dismissed by either a single and simplistic example
column9: by some self-appoined talking head
column10: by employees who like their jobs
column11: or simply by people passing by on the street.  I found this pathetically unconvincing.   For example
column12: because wal-mart is criticised as a destructive force against traditional town centers
column13: the filmmakers find one town that was able to renew itself as a tourist spot with boutiquie stores and then assumes that that can happen everywhere (but the site was in the Blue Mountains
column14: not in the Oklahoma dustbowl).  No statistics are offered
column15: no additional proof
column16: and no counter-arguments are acknowledged.     Moreover
column17: it is easy to find people to spout the opinion you want to espouse by looking for them - to be sure
column18: wal-mart critics do the same
column19: but there are some critics who act like journalists and try to see what truth there is in the arguments advanced.  This film does not.   At one point
column20: the filmakers interview a group of teenagers who state wal-mart wages would  "enough" for them (none of them work there)
column21: as if that refutes the experience of single mothers trying to make ends meet on wal-mart salaries!  They also get a few people to state that they never get asked to work overtime wothout pay as if that eliminates the need to investigate the claims of thousands of others who are winning multi-million dollar class-action lawsuits against that practice in their wal-marts.  Finally
column22: some of the talking heads make the most ridiculous arguments.  One of them dismissed all the arguments of critics who charge that wal-mart urges its workers to use the welfare system as "those who advocate government health care anyway" - as if that negates their arguments!  By glossing over the details
column23: they don't even make the case in  favor of the wal-mart business model all that well
column24: let alone consider how the intallation of a wal-mart impacts entire communities.  As such
column25: this film is for the convinced
column26: for those who want to have their opinions reinforced rather than challenged.  That makes it like Fox news at its worst:  you know what you are going to get before you switch it on - pure opinion and little reporting - so why bother?  It isn't for learning.  The costs behind wal-mart's methods are not even open to question.  The one thing I took away from this is the sincerity of some of the employees
column27: who genuinely believed in the company.    Overall
column28: I cannot recommend this film
column29: except as a pure ideological view in favor of this controversial company.   This doesn't do anyone any good - there is no chance for dialogue in this approach
column30: no acknowledgment that critics can make legitimate points.  Whether powerful companies like it or not
column31: they do not automatically deserve our trust
column32: but instead our critical and constant scrutiny

column1: Despite its' title
column2: this book (wide page margins and large type actually make it a distended pamphlet) is only incidentally about Pope Pius XII.  Its' real purpose is to set Roman Catholics and Muslims at each others throats
column3: and to lead Catholics to support any and all actions taken by the Israeli government against Palestinians living within Israeli-occupied territory.  It tries to accomplish this by tarring all Arabs (and by implication
column4: all Muslims) as subhuman beasts.  Throughout this noisome tract
column5: Arabs--wherever and whenever found--are relentlessly portrayed as the exact equivalent to Nazis and vice-versa.  This technique scarcely differs from that of crude anti-Jewish screeds that go from noting that Karl Marx and the Rosenbergs were Jews
column6: to claiming that Jews and Communists are one and the same.  Pius is used merely as a foil to a contemporary
column7: the notorious Nazi-sympathizer
column8: Haji Amin al-Hussaini
column9: the Grand Mufti of Jerusalem.  Considering what a low basis for comparison this is
column10: one hopes that at least some Catholics will take offense at the Pope being dragged alongside such a grotesque figure.  Not a trace of original research or primary sources besmirch these pristine pages.  Instead
column11: the book deliberately conflates two separate and highly emotive issues which will be untangled here.  1.) Pope Pius XII
column12: the Holocaust
column13: and the Jews:  For whatever it is worth
column14: this reviewer believes Pius was caught in an almost impossible situation.  Not only was there legitimate concern that more forceful denunciations of Nazi genocide might backfire; the Pope himself stood in danger of kidnap
column15: capture or murder.  Hitler certainly would not have had the least compunction about such methods; a head of state such as deposed Austrian Prime Minister Kurt von Schuschnigg was imprisoned in a concentration camp until the end of the war
column16: barely escaping execution at the last.    Questions concerning Pius' precise actions during the war have now been thoroughly muddled and muddied by sloppy research
column17: overstatement
column18: and much venom squirted by both Pius' extreme critics and extreme defenders (this book very definitely included).  A recent scrupulously fair and rigidly factual examination of these matters is "Pius XII and the Holocaust: Understanding the Controversy"  by  historian Jose M. Sanchez (available from Amazon).  Regrettably
column19: it will probably be ignored.  Everyone seems bent on finding another prosecutor's charge sheet or defense attorney's brief to augment their pre-fab opinions.  2.) Israel
column20: the Arab States
column21: and the Palestinians:  By now
column22: the struggle between (and within) these groups has become so poisonous
column23: archangels with Ph.D.'s in International Relations would be hard pressed to come up with a solution to the conflict all sides could accept.  To bitter partisans on either side equipped with guns
column24: bombs
column25: microphones
column26: or pens; no falsehood is too gross
column27: no libel too base
column28: and no tactic too vile.  By contrast
column29: Catholics (as well as Christians generally) have a Just War tradition against which all sides are to be judged.  Hopefully
column30: this ugly attempt to further poison the wells of controversy will be seen for what it is.    Perhaps the author should be congratulated; he has managed to becloud and envenom not just one
column31: but two hotly contested topics in 256 brief pages.  Nazi propagandists called this tactic `zersetzung' (literally: decomposition).  How curious to find a rabbi resorting to it

column1: I am a Navy Wife of four years facing my first deployment as a wife and I found this book to be the corniest thing I've ever read. EVER.  The "comical" stories everyone seems to be gushing over sound like they were pulled right out of a dusty old Reader's Digest. I didn't find the book to be informative and I found the definition section of the book to be incredibly trite and boring.   Example: Term Active Duty
column2: Military Speak: Actively serving and deployable. Spouse Speak: This means your address is written in pencil in address books.  Dear God. How incredibly lame. Military members move. Yes. It's true. We ALL know that. Civilians know this. EVERYONE knows this. This poor attempt at humor is dull and over-used.  I didn't learn ANYTHING from this book and would NOT recommend this to anyone  SERIOUSLY looking for information or advice about military life or deployments. You can get USEFUL information by going to your local Fleet and Family Support Center or attending a pre-deployment brief.

column1: There is actually a lot of interesting historical information for the right-of-center reader who wants to learn about the right-wing/Republican successes in bolstering its face time in the American media.   But it's a tough read because Brock is obviously extremely skeptical of pretty much everything that comes out of the mouth of anyone who votes Republican.   Brock hurts his credibility early on when he states flat out that his early conservative writings were actually literary regurgitations of the right wing party line. But what's to keep a reader from viewing this book as just a left-wing version of the same?  I think he could have balanced the book by discussing more specific left-of-center successes. Whenever he does mention the left-wing in the media
column2: it's usually in lofty platitudes about their objectivity and non-partisanship (trust me
column3: Brock really believes this).   He seems to think the left-wing is totally helpless in the face of the right-wing media juggernaut. Does anyone in America actually believe that?  This book has the potential to be an informative read (it's over 400 pages)
column4: but it too often lapses into name calling
column5: unsubstantiated generalizations
column6: and conspiratorial excess.   Leave the wild rhetoric to Michael Moore and just give us the facts

column1: This book has been summarized already by previous reviewers

column3: it seemed as if Shattuck couldn't decide whether the book should be literary criticism or historical overview or a chance for him to air out his morals. He tried to do all three at once
column4: resulting in a bit of a mess. He kept switching back and forth between objective history lesson and subjective moralizing to the point where the points he professed to be trying to make became somewhat lost and pointless. The objective bits were dry and boring and the moralizing was condescending and annoying and insulting to the reader

column5: especially Pink Slip and Blue Italian are so much better. I've been trying to unload this on ebay for a long time now and no one will buy it from me. Can't say I blame them

column1: I got this product for my daughter. My daughter often could not make the journal open. After a frunstrating week or two

column1: Don't get me wrong
column2: I love Brian Stokes Mitchell. His deep voice is intoxicating and beautiful

column4: I'll be the first in line

column1: In the wake of corporate scandals
column2: David Callahan decided to look into cheating in America.  What he discovered was the cheating has become part of our social structure. He attributes this to the intense pressure that society puts on us to succeed.  Since many high profile people cheat and are not caught (and if they do the penalty is low)
column3: many other people begin to cheat because they feel that they have to stay at the same level as others.  This causes cheating behavior to "trickle-down" until it almost become socially acceptable.  He even mentions how people begin to cheat at a young age in school
column4: and when they do not get caught
column5: they continue to cheat throughout their lives because they see the benefits are greater than the chance of getting caught and being punished.  Additionally
column6: he says how many people cheat even when they do not recognize their behavior as cheating
column7: such as when they steal cable or download music for free.  This book is based on a good idea
column8: and Callahan does give many real world examples.  The major downfall of the book is that with every example he reaches the same conclusion
column9: which is more or less
column10: what I described above.  After reading this for a couple hundred pages
column11: it becomes redundant and mind numbing.  By the time you reach the chapter on how to solve the problem
column12: you already know what his solution is because he repeats it throughout the book.  I feel that this book would have been a lot better if it were only half as long.

column1: Anita Shreve is pushing an agenda
column2: but not necessarily a moral one.  Yes
column3: Fortune Rocks contains many truthes...teenaged mothers shouldn't be ostracized from society
column4: and are still people worthy of love
column5: but ultimately the book tries to make adultery acceptable.  This book depressed me.  Not only because Shreve never admits that most of the suffering could've been averted by different (and wiser) choices
column6: but because her amoral thinking is cleverly couched between truthes and half-truthes.  I also hate reading books that make hot
column7: infatuation sex the highest possible endeavor in life
column8: and that all else (especially a good marriage and children) should be sacrificed for it.

column1: In 5th grade my reading group was assigned this book. We all hated it because Gilly was an obnoxious
column2: snotty brat. We spent most of our work time drawing comics in which she crawled out of the school toilets and attacked us
column3: and we had to fight back and defeat the evil Gilly. So if you want your kids to waste time
column4: buy this book; if you actually want them to read something meaningful and enjoyable
column5: look elsewhere.  However
column6: I do have to say that we weren't at all shocked or corrupted by the language. Kids learn that stuff anyway

column1: I just want to say
column2: do not judge the author by this book.  I loved Ugly Duckling and many of her romance novels
column3: but this one was terrible.  The hero of the novel starts out being strong and interesting
column4: but for no aparent reason turns into a spineless idiot.  Bess
column5: the heroine
column6: acted like a selfish
column7: hypocritical child and was never once brought to task for her stupidity.  She spends half of the novel blaming Kaldack for risking her life for the good of many
column8: but spends the entire novel risking not only herself but everyone else for more selfish motives.  As the bodies pile up as a result of her actions
column9: she never acknowledges any culpability.  I completely agree with every bad review that has been written

Great Expectations was a mediocre book.  I was not impressed.  I had to read this book for my 9th grade honors English class.  It was too long and boring.  I see were Dickens was trying to go with the suspense
column2: but it just made the book monotonous and boring. The uncanny coincidences just did not seem real.  It's ok to use a coincidence as a tool of suspense
column3: but this was just overkill.  Every chapter was boring.  I got tired pretty quickly of pip wishing he were with Estella for the whole book.  Also
column4: the book seemed to stray away from the main point for chapters at a time. Who cares about Wemmick's stupid plays?  This could all be summed up in a couple of page short story.  In conclusion
column5: this is another swing and a miss for Dickens.  STAY FAR AWAY FROM THIS BOOK!  If you want to read a good Dickens story
column6: read "A Christmas Carol" and nothing else written by Charles Dickens

column1: I found the book thought-provoking
column2: but there is more to philosophy than provocation. The common underlying argument of this book
column3: and its only valid statement as ethics
column4: is that since the only purpose of ethics is to regulate human behavior
column5: the ethics society adopts should reflect the kind of society we want to live in. This results-oriented approach is all very well
column6: but Singer doesn't really build upon it through any legitimate philosophical argument. Virtually all of Singer's arguments about particular issues rest upon emotional premises that the reader either does or does not accept. If you accept the premise you are likely to find at least some merit in the argument; if you don't accept the premise
column7: its impossible to follow along to any useful conclusion. In short
column8: these are not ethical writings but the political writings of someone who is too smart for standard political discourse and not interested in limiting his thoughts to philsophy as a discipline. How useful you find this is up to you. I personally don't know Singer from Adam and had not received any prior indoctrination about how groundbreaking he was before I picked up the book; as a result
column9: I have trouble seeing what people are so excited about

column1: Terry Pratchett's only written four bad books of which I am aware. This
column2: I suppose
column3: is a sign of genius -- when your work is so consistently good that a small slip-up is so glaringly obvious. It doesn't help Carpe Jugulum
column4: though.  The Witches are the least interesting of Pratchett's sub-worlds
column5: since Granny Weatherwax is simply too confident and sure of herself for us to really believe that anything can threaten her. Her cohorts are simply not as funny or interesting as Death's family
column6: the University Wizards
column7: or the Night Watch.  The storyline here is also something we've seen many times before; something strange and modern is invading the Discworld
column8: and the native forces have to oppose it. In this case
column9: the threat is a bunch of vampires who play by modern rules instead of traditional; they like garlic
column10: they ignore holy symbols
column11: and so forth. The Witches mobilize to oppose them using a combination of clever tricks (which don't really make sense) and blind optimism (basically just hoping something lucky will happen). The subplots involve the arrival of an Omnian revivalist in Lancre
column12: some strange avian life
column13: and a bit more of the fairy-tale clich from Witches Abroad; none of these subplots actually go anywhere.  Really
column14: this is the exact same plot as Lords and Ladies
column15: but not as well executed. It's still not Pratchett's worst (that's hands-down Fifth Elephant) but it's certainly nearly as much fun to read as his other works

column1: Too bad that the last of the Ripley books was a bit of a let-down.  A great set up and interesting premise
column2: the book is marred by its poor resolution.  What potential - two vulgar Americans who become Ripley's neighbors with a hidden agenda...the "cat and mouse" of this book should have been great
column3: but sadly it falls short.  In my opinion
column4: Ripley's Game is the best of the Ripley sequels - this one doesn't even come close..

column1: Scraping and processing the web for data is increasingly interesting to blooming social scientists.  With the availability of the BeautifulSoup library
column2: these occasional programmers are now able to slice & dice HTML with regular expressions.  But they shouldn't use this book to help them scrape the data from the Internet.  Reading this book and using its examples
column3: one might conclude that cookies don't exist on the Web.  If you're looking for solid Web examples or networking example code
column4: don't look here.  This section of the book is in need of a re-tune
